docTitle.titlePart: THE LAND OF PROMISE A COMEDY IN FOUR ACTS

titlePage.docImprint: All applications regarding the Performance Rights of this play should be addressed to Mr. R. Golding Bright , 20 , Green Street , Leicester Square ,London, W. C. 2 . This play was produced on February 26 ,1914, at the Duke of York ’ s Theatre , with the following cast : NORAH MARSH Irene Vanbrugh . EDWARD MARSH C. V.France. GERTRUDE MARSH Marion Ashworth . FRANK TAYLOR Godfrey Tearle . REGINALD HORNBY Basil Foster . BENJAMIN TROTTER George Tully . SIDNEY SHARP J. Woodall-Birde . EMMA SHARP Mary Rorke . JAMES WICKHAM Athol Stewart . DOROTHY WICKHAM Netta Westcott . AGNES PRINGLE Lena Halliday . CLEMENT WYNNE Charles Goodwin . KATE Marion Christie Murray .

set.p: The action of the play takes place at Tunbridge Wells , and later in Canada .

div.head: ACT I

stage.stage: SCENE : The drawing-room at Miss Wickham ’ s house in Tunbridge Wells . It is a room in which there is too much furniture . There are armchairs covered with faded chintz , little tables here and there , cabinets containing china , a great many photographs in silver frames , porcelain ornaments wherever there is a vacant space , Chippendale chairs and chairs from the Tottenham Court Road . There are flowers in vases and growing plants . The wall-paper has a pattern of enormous chrysanthemums , and on the walls are a large number of old-fashioned watercolours in gilt frames . There is one door , which leads into the hall ; and a French window opens on to the garden . The window is decorated with white lace curtains . It is four o ’ clock in the afternoon . The sun is streaming through the drawn blinds . There is a wreath of white flowers in a cardboard box on one of the chairs . The door is opened by KATE , the parlour-maid . She is of respectable appearance and of a decent age . She admits MISS PRINGLE . MISS PRINGLE is companion to a wealthy old lady in Tunbridge Wells . She is a woman of middle age , plainly dressed , thin and narrow of shoulders , with a weather-beaten , tired face and grey hair .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: I ’ ll tell Miss Marsh you ’ re here , Miss Pringle .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: How is she to-day , Kate ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: She ’ s tired out , poor thing . She ’ s lying down now . But I ’ m sure she ’ d like to see you , Miss .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: I ’ m very glad she didn ’ t go to the funeral .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Dr. Evans thought she ’ d better stay at home , Miss , and Mrs. Wickham said she ’ d only upset herself if she went .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: I wonder how she stood it all those months , waiting on Miss Wickham hand and foot .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Miss Wickham wouldn ’ t have a professional nurse . And you know what she was , Miss .... Miss Marsh slept in Miss Wickham ’ s room , and the moment she fell asleep Miss Wickham would have her up because her pillow wanted shaking , or she was thirsty , or something .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: I suppose she was very inconsiderate .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Inconsiderate isn ’ t the word , Miss . I wouldn ’ t be a lady ’ s companion , not for anything . What they have to put up with !

lg.l: Oh , well , everyone isn ’ t like Miss Wickham . The lady I ’ m companion to ,
Mrs. Hubbard , is kindness itself .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: That sounds like Miss Marsh coming downstairsShe goes to the door and opens it .Miss Pringle is here , Miss .

div.stage: NORAH comes in . She is a woman of twenty-eight , with a pleasant , honest face and a happy smile . She is gentle , with quiet manners , but she has a quick temper , under very good control , and a passionate nature which is hidden under a demure appearance . She is simply dressed in black .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I am glad to see you . I was hoping you ’ d be able to come here this afternoon .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: Mrs. Hubbard has gone for a drive with somebody or other , and didn ’ t want me .

div.stage: They kiss one another . NORAH notices the wreath .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What ’ s this ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: It didn ’ t arrive till after they ’ d started , Miss .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I wonder whom it ’ s from .She looks at a card which is attached to the wreath .“ From Mrs. Alfred Vincent , with deepest regret for my dear Miss Wickham and heartiest sympathy for her sorrowing relatives .”

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Sorrowing relatives is good , Miss .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Remonstrating .Kate ... I think you ’ d better take it away .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: What shall I do with it , Miss ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ m going to the cemetery a little later . I ’ ll take it with me .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Very good , Miss .

div.stage: KATE takes up the box and goes out .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: You haven ’ t been crying , Norah ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a little apologetic smile .Yes , I couldn ’ t help it .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: What on earth for ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: My dear , it ’ s not unnatural .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: Well , I don ’ t want to say anything against her now she ’ s dead and gone , poor thing , but Miss Wickham was the most detestable old woman I ever met .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I don ’ t suppose one can live all that time with anyone and not be a little sorry to part with them for ever . I was Miss Wickham ’ s companion for ten years .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: How you stood it ! Exacting , domineering , disagreeable .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Yes , I suppose she was . Because she paid me a salary she thought I wasn ’ t a human being . I never saw anyone with such a bitter tongue . At first I used to cry every night when I went to bed because of the things she said to me . But I got used to them .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: I wonder you didn ’ t leave her . I would have .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: It ’ s not easy to get posts as lady ’ s companion .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: That ’ s true . They tell me the agents ’ books are full of people wanting situations . Before I went to Mrs. Hubbard I was out of one for nearly two years .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: It ’ s not so bad for you . You can always go and stay with your brother .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: You ’ ve got a brother too .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Yes , but he ’ s farming in Canada . He had all he could do to keep himself , he couldn ’ t keep me too .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: How is he doing now ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , he ’ s doing very well . He ’ s got a farm of his own . He wrote over a couple of years ago and told me he could always give me a home if I wanted one .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: Canada ’ s so far off .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Not when you get there .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: Why don ’ t you draw the blinds ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I thought I ought to wait till they come back from the funeral .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: It must be a great relief to you now it ’ s all over .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Sometimes I can ’ t realise it . These last few weeks I hardly got to bed at all , and when the end came I was utterly exhausted . For two days I could do nothing but sleep . Poor Miss Wickham . She did hate dying .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: That ’ s the extraordinary part of it . I believe you were really fond of her .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: D ’ you know that for nearly a year she would eat nothing but what I gave her with my own hands . And she liked me as much as she was capable of liking anybody .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: That wasn ’ t much .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: And then , I was so dreadfully sorry for her .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: Good heavens !

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: She ’ d been a hard and selfish woman all her life , and there was no one who cared for her . It seemed so dreadful to die like that and leave not a soul to regret one . Her nephew and his wife were just waiting for her death . It was dreadful . Each time they came down from London I saw them looking at her to see if she was any worse than when last they ’ d seen her .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: Well , I thought her a horrid old woman , and I ’ m glad she ’ s dead . And I hope she ’ s left you well provided for .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a smile .Oh , I think she ’ s done that . Two years ago when I nearly went away she said she ’ d left me enough to live upon .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: You mean when that assistant of Dr. Evans wanted to marry you ? I ’ m glad you wouldn ’ t have him .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: He was very nice . But , of course , he wasn ’ t a gentleman .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: I shouldn ’ t like to live with a man at all ; I think they ’ re horrid , but , of course , it would be impossible if he weren ’ t a gentleman .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a twinkle in her eye .He came to see Miss Wickham , but she wouldn ’ t have anything to do with him . First she said that she couldn ’ t spare me , and then she said that I had a very bad temper .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: I like her saying that .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: It ’ s quite true . Every now and then I felt I couldn ’ t put up with her any more . I forgot that I was dependent on her , and if she dismissed me I probably shouldn ’ t be able to find another situation , and I just flew at her . I must say she was very nice about it ; she used to look at me and grin , and , when it was all over , say : “ My dear , when you marry , if your husband ’ s a wise man , he ’ ll use a big stick now and then .”

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: Old cat .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Smiling .I should like to see a man try .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: How much d ’ you think she ’ s left you ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Well , of course , I don ’ t know ; the will is going to be read this afternoon when they come back from the funeral , but from what she said I believe about two hundred and fifty a year .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: It ’ s the least she could do . She ’ s had the ten best years of your life .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a sigh of relief .I shall never be at anybody ’ s beck and call again . I shall be able to get up when I like and go to bed when I like , go out when I choose , and come in when I choose .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: Drily .You ’ ll probably marry .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Never .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: Then what ’ ll you do ?

lg.l: I shall go to Italy , Florence , Rome . D ’ you think it ’ s horrible of me ,
I ’ m so happy ?

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: My dear child .

div.stage: There is a sound of carriage wheels on the drive .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: There they are .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: I ’ d better go , hadn ’ t I ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ m afraid you must .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: I do so want to know about the will . Can ’ t I go up to your room and wait there ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: No . I ’ ll tell you what , go and sit in the garden . They want to catch the four something back to London , and we can have a cosy little tea all by ourselves .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: Very well . Oh , my dear , I ’ m so happy in your good luck .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Take care .

div.stage: MISS PRINGLE slips out into the garden , and a moment later MR. and MRS. WICKHAM enter the room . MRS. WICKHAM is a pretty young woman . She is dressed in black , but her gown is elegant and fashionable . JAMES WICKHAM is a clean-shaven , thin-faced man , with a baldish head . He is dressed in black and wears black kid gloves .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Cheerfully .Ouf ! Do put the blinds up , Miss Marsh . We really needn ’ t be depressed any more . Jim , if you love me , take those gloves off . They ’ re perfectly revolting .

div.stage: NORAH goes to the window and draws up the blind .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Why , what ’ s wrong with them ? The fellow in the shop told me they were the right thing .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: I never saw anyone look quite so funereal as you do .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Well , you didn ’ t want me to get myself up as though I were going to a wedding , did you ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Were there many people ?

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Quite a lot . The sort of people who indulge in other people ’ s funerals as a mild form of dissipation .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Looking at his watch .I hope Wynne will look sharp . I don ’ t want to miss that train .

lg.l: Who were all those stodgy old things who wrung your hand afterwards ,
Jim ?

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: I can ’ t think . They made me feel such a fool .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Oh , was that it ? I saw you looking a perfect owl , and I thought you were giving a very bad imitation of restrained emotion .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Remonstrating .Dorothy .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Would you like some tea , Mrs. Wickham ?

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Well , you might send some in so that it ’ ll be ready when Mr. Wynne comes .NORAH is just going to ring the bell , but MRS. WICKHAM stops her with a pleasant smile .We ’ ll ring for you , shall we ? I daresay you ’ ve got one or two things you want to do now .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Very good , Mrs. Wickham .

div.stage: She goes out .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: I say , Dorothy , you oughtn ’ t to be facetious before Miss Marsh . She was extremely attached to Aunt Louisa .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Oh , what nonsense ! It ’ s always a very good rule to judge people by oneself , and I ’ m positive she was just longing for the old lady to die .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: She was awfully upset at the end .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Nerves ! Men are so idiotic . They never understand that there are tears and tears . I cried myself , and heaven knows I didn ’ t regret her death .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: My dear Dorothy , you oughtn ’ t to say that .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Why not ? It ’ s perfectly true . Aunt Louisa was a detestable person and no one would have stood her for a minute if she hadn ’ t had money . I don ’ t see any use in being a hypocrite now that it can ’ t make any difference either way .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Looking at his watch again .I wish Wynne would hurry up . It ’ ll be beastly inconvenient if we miss that train .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: I don ’ t trust Miss Marsh . She looks as if she knew what was in the will .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: I don ’ t suppose she does . Aunt Louisa wasn ’ t the sort of person to talk .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: I ’ m sure she knows she ’ s been left something .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Oh , well , I think she has a right to expect that . Aunt Louisa led her a dog ’ s life .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: She had wages and a comfortable home . If she didn ’ t like the place she could have left it .... After all it ’ s family money . I don ’ t think Aunt Louisa had the right to leave it to strangers .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: We oughtn ’ t to complain if Miss Marsh gets a small annuity . Aunt Louisa promised her something of the sort when she had a chance of marrying a couple of years ago .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Miss Marsh is quite young . It isn ’ t as if she ’ d been here for thirty years .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Well , I ’ ve got an idea that Aunt Louisa meant to leave her about two hundred and fifty a year .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: But what ’ s the estate ?

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: About nineteen thousand pounds , I believe .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Oh , it ’ s absurd . It ’ s a most unfair proportion . It makes all the difference to us . On that extra two hundred and fifty a year we could almost keep a car .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: My dear , be thankful if we get anything at all .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Aghast .Jim !She stares at him .Jim , you don ’ t think ! Oh ! That would be too horrible .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Take care .The door opens and KATE brings in the tea-things . She puts them on a small table .How lucky it is we had a fine day , isn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: It looks as if we were going to have a spell of fine weather .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: It ’ s funny how often it rains for weddings .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Very funny .Exit KATE .I ’ ve been counting on that money for years . I used to dream at night that I was reading a telegram with the news of Aunt Louisa ’ s death . And I ’ ve thought of all we should be able to do when we got it . It ’ ll make such a difference .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: You know what she was . She didn ’ t care two-pence for us . We ought to be prepared for the worst .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: D ’ you think she could have left everything to Miss Marsh ?

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: I shouldn ’ t be surprised .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: We ’ ll dispute the will . It ’ s undue influence . I suspected Miss Marsh from the beginning . I hate her . Oh , why doesn ’ t Wynne come ?

div.stage: There is a ring at the bell .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Here he is , I expect .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: The suspense is too awful .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Pull yourself together , old girl . And I say , look a bit dismal . After all , we ’ ve just come from a funeral .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Are we downhearted ?

div.stage: KATE enters to announce MR. WYNNE .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Mr. Wynne .

div.stage: He enters and she goes out and closes the door . MR. WYNNE , the late Miss Wickham ’ s solicitor , is a tallish man with a bald head . He has the red cheeks and hearty manner of a man who plays in his spare time at being a country gentleman . He is dressed in mourning because he has been to Miss Wickham ’ s funeral .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Hulloa !

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: Taking DOROTHY ’ S hand rather solemnly .I didn ’ t have an opportunity of shaking hands with you at the cemetery .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Somewhat helplessly .How do you do ?

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: Pray accept my sincerest sympathy on your great bereavement .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Of course , the end was not entirely unexpected .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: No , I know . But it must have been a great shock all the same .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: My wife was very much upset , but of course my poor aunt had suffered great pain , and we couldn ’ t help looking upon it as a happy release .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: How is Miss Marsh ?

div.stage: DOROTHY gives him a quick look , wondering whether there is anything behind the polite inquiry .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Oh , she ’ s very well .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: Her devotion to Miss Wickham was wonderful . Dr. Evans — he ’ s my brother-in-law , you know — told me no trained nurse could have been more competent . She was like a daughter to Miss Wickham .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Rather coldly .I suppose we ’ d better send for her .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Have you brought the ....He stops in some embarrassment .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: Yes , I have it in my pocket .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: I ’ ll ring .

div.stage: She touches the bell .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: I expect Mr. Wynne would like a cup of tea , Dorothy .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Oh , I ’ m so sorry , I quite forgot about it .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: No , thank you very much . I never take tea .

div.stage: He takes a long envelope out of his pocket , and from it the will . He smooths it out reflectively . DOROTHY gives the document a nervous glance . KATE comes in .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Will you ask Miss Marsh to be good enough to come here .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Very good , sir .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: What is the time , Jim ?

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Looking at his watch .Oh , there ’ s no hurry .To WYNNE .We ’ ve got an important engagement in London this evening . We ’ re very anxious not to miss the fast train .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: The train service is rotten .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: The will is very short . It won ’ t take me two minutes to read it .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Nervous and impatient .What on earth is Miss Marsh doing ?

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: How pretty the garden is looking now .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Abruptly .Very .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: Miss Wickham was always so interested in her garden .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: My own tulips aren ’ t so advanced as those .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Irritably .Aren ’ t they ?

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: To DOROTHY .Are you interested in gardening ?

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Hardly able to control her impatience .No , I hate it .... At last !

div.stage: The door is opened and MISS MARSH comes in . WYNNE gets up .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: How d ’ you do , Miss Marsh ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: How d ’ you do ?

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Will you have a cup of tea ?

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: All nerves .Jim , Miss Marsh would much prefer to have tea quietly after we ’ re gone .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a faint smile .I won ’ t have any tea , thank you .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Mr. Wynne has brought the will with him .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , yes .

div.stage: She sits down calmly . DOROTHY , with clenched hands , watches her . She tries to make out from her face whether NORAH knows anything .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: Miss Marsh , so far as you know , there ’ s no other will ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: How d ’ you mean ?

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: Miss Wickham didn ’ t make a later one — without my assistance , I mean ? You know of nothing in the house , for instance ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Quite decidedly .Oh , no . Miss Wickham always said you had her will . She was extremely methodical .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: I feel I ought to ask because she consulted me about making a fresh will a couple of years ago . She told me what she wanted to do , but gave me no actual instructions to draw it . I thought perhaps she might have done it herself .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I heard nothing about it . I ’ m sure that her only will is in your hands .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: Then I think we may take it that this ....

div.stage: DOROTHY suddenly understands ; she interrupts quickly .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: When was that will made ?

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: Eight or nine years ago .... The exact date was March 4th , 1904 .

div.stage: DOROTHY gives Norah a long , searching look .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: When did you first come to Miss Wickham ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: At the end of nineteen hundred and three .

div.stage: There is a slight pause .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: Shall I read it , or would you just like to know the particulars ? It is very short .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Let us just know roughly .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: Well , Miss Wickham left one hundred pounds to the Society for the Propagation of the Gospel , and one hundred pounds to the General Hospital at Tunbridge Wells , and the entire residue of her fortune to her nephew , Mr. James Wickham .

div.stage: DOROTHY gives a sharp inspiration of triumph . She looks again at NORAH , but NORAH gives no sign of emotion .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: And Miss Marsh ?

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: Miss Marsh is not mentioned .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a faint smile .I could hardly expect to be . At the time the will was drawn I had been Miss Wickham ’ s companion for only a few months .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: That is why I asked whether you knew of any later will . When I talked to Miss Wickham on the subject she said her wish was to make adequate provision for you after her death . I think she had spoken to you about it .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: She mentioned three hundred a year .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: That was very kind of her . I ’ m glad she wished to do something for me .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: Oddly enough she spoke about it to Dr. Evans only a few days before she died .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Perhaps there is a later will somewhere ?

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: I honestly don ’ t think so .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ m sure there isn ’ t .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: Dr. Evans was talking to Miss Wickham about Miss Marsh . She was tired out and he wanted Miss Wickham to have a professional nurse . She told him then that I had the will and she had left Miss Marsh amply provided for .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Quickly .That isn ’ t legal , of course ?

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: What isn ’ t ?

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: I mean , no one could force us — I mean , the will stands as it is , doesn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: I ’ m afraid it ’ s a great disappointment to you , Miss Marsh .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Lightly .I never count my chickens before they ’ re hatched .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: It would be very natural if Miss Marsh were disappointed under the circumstances . I think she ’ d been led to expect ....

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Interrupting .Our aunt left a very small fortune , I understand , and I suppose she felt it wouldn ’ t be fair to leave a large part of it away from her own family .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Of course , it is family money ; she inherited it from my grandfather , and ... but I want you to know , Miss Marsh , that my wife and I thoroughly appreciate all you did for my aunt . Money couldn ’ t repay your care and devotion . You ’ ve been perfectly wonderful .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: It ’ s extremely good of you to say so . I was very fond of Miss Wickham . Nothing I did for her was any trouble .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: I think everyone who saw Miss Marsh with Miss Wickham must be aware that during the ten years she was with her she never spared herself .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Hesitatingly , with a glance at his wife .Of course , my aunt was a very trying woman .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Agreeably .Earning one ’ s living is always unpleasant . If it weren ’ t there ’ d be no incentive to work .

div.stage: NORAH gives her a glance of quiet amusement at this surprising remark .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: My wife and I would be very glad to make some kind of acknowledgment of your services .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: I was just going to mention it .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: Brightening a little .I felt sure that under the circumstances ....

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Interrupting him quickly .What were your wages , Miss Marsh ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Thirty pounds a year .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Really ? Many ladies are glad to go as companion without any salary , just for the sake of a home and congenial society . I daresay you ’ ve been able to save a good deal in all these years .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Frigidly .I had to dress myself decently , Mrs. Wickham .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: With all the charm she can put into her manner .Well , I ’ m sure my husband will be very glad to give you a year ’ s salary , won ’ t you , Jim ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: It ’ s very kind of you , but I ’ m not inclined to accept anything but what ’ s legally due to me .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Undisturbed .You must remember that there ’ ll be very heavy death duties to pay . They ’ ll swallow up the income from Miss Wickham ’ s estate for at least two years , won ’ t they , Mr. Wynne ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I quite understand .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Perhaps you ’ ll change your mind .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I don ’ t think so .

div.stage: There is a slight , rather awkward pause . MR. WYNNE gets up . His manner shows that he is not impressed by MRS. WICKHAM ’ S generosity .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: Well , I think I must leave you .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: We must go , too , Dorothy .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Quite at ease .Oh , it ’ ll only take five minutes to get down to the station in a cab .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: Good-bye , Miss Marsh . If I can be of any help to you I hope you ’ ll let me know .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: That ’ s very kind of you .

sp.speaker: WYNNE
sp.p: To DOROTHY .Good-bye .

div.stage: He bows slightly to her , nods to WICKHAM and during DOROTHY ’ S next speech goes out .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: Very friendly and affable .Jim will be writing to you in a day or two . You know how grateful we both are for all you did for our poor aunt . We shall be glad to give you the very highest references .

sp.speaker: WICKHAM
sp.p: Relieved to be able to offer something .Oh , yes , we ’ ll do everything we can .

sp.speaker: DOROTHY
sp.p: You ’ re such a wonderful nurse , I ’ m sure you ’ ll have no difficulty in getting another situation . I expect I can find you something myself . I ’ ll ask among all my friends .

div.stage: NORAH looks at her reflectively , but does not answer . DOROTHY beams and smiles at her .

lg.l: Come on , Dorothy , we really haven ’ t got any time to lose . Good-bye , Miss
Marsh .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Good-bye .

div.stage: They bustle out and in a moment the sound is heard of wheels on the drive as the cab carries them away . NORAH is left alone . She stands staring in front of her . She does not hear MISS PRINGLE come in from the garden .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: I thought they were never going . Well ?

div.stage: NORAH turns and looks at her without a word .
MISS PRINGLE is startled . ] Norah ! What ’ s the matter ? Isn ’ t it as much as you thought ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Miss Wickham ’ s left me nothing .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Not a penny ! Oh , it ’ s cruel . After all , there was no need for her to leave me anything . She gave me board and lodging and thirty pounds a year . If I stayed it was because I chose . She needn ’ t have promised me anything . She needn ’ t have prevented me from marrying .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: My dear , you could never have married the little assistant . He wasn ’ t a gentleman .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Ten years ! The ten best years of a woman ’ s life , when other girls are enjoying themselves . And what did I get for it ? Board and lodging and thirty pounds a year . A cook does better than that .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: We can ’ t expect to make so much money as a good cook . One has to pay something for living like a lady among people of one ’ s own class .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , it ’ s cruel .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: Trying to console her .My dear , don ’ t give way . I ’ m sure you ’ ll have no difficulty in finding another situation . You wash lace beautifully , and no one can arrange flowers like you .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I was dreaming of France and Italy .... I shall spend ten years more with an old lady , and then she ’ ll die , and I shall look out for another situation . It won ’ t be so easy then because I shan ’ t be so young . And so it ’ ll go on till I can ’ t find a situation because I ’ m too old , and some charitable people will get me into a home . You like the life , don ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: My dear , there are so few things a gentlewoman can do .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: When I think of these ten years ! Having to put up with every unreasonableness ! Never being allowed to feel ill or tired ! No servant would have stood what I have . The humiliation I ’ ve endured !

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: You ’ re tired and out of sorts . Everyone isn ’ t so trying as Miss Wickham . I ’ m sure Mrs. Hubbard has been kindness itself to me .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Considering .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: I don ’ t know what you mean by considering .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Considering that she ’ s rich and you ’ re poor . She gives you her old clothes . She often doesn ’ t ask you to have dinner by yourself when she ’ s giving a party . She doesn ’ t remind you that you ’ re dependent unless she ’ s very much put out . But you — you ’ ve had thirty years of it . You ’ ve eaten the bitter bread of slavery till — till it tastes like plum cake .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: Rather hurt .I don ’ t know why you say such things to me , Norah .

div.stage: Before NORAH has time to answer KATE comes in .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Mr. Hornby would like to see you for a minute , Miss .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Surprised .Now ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: I told him I didn ’ t think it would be convenient , Miss , but he says it ’ s very important , and he won ’ t detain you more than five minutes .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What a nuisance .... Ask him to come in .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Very good , Miss .Exit .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I wonder what on earth he wants .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: Who is he , Norah ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , he ’ s the son of Colonel Hornby . Don ’ t you know , he lives at the top of Molyneux Park . His mother was a great friend of Miss Wickham ’ s . He comes down here now and then for week-ends . He ’ s got something to do with motor-cars .

div.stage: KATE shows the visitor in .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Mr. Hornby .

div.stage: She goes out . REGINALD HORNBY is a good-looking young man , with a neat head on a long , elegant body . His dark , sleek hair is carefully brushed , his small moustache is trim and curled . His beautiful clothes suggest the fashionable tailors of Savile Row . His tie , his handkerchief protruding from the breast pocket , his boots , are the very latest thing . He is a nut .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: I say , I ’ m awfully sorry to blow in like this . But I didn ’ t know if you ’ d be staying on here , and I wanted to catch you . And I ’ m off in a day or two , myself .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Won ’ t you sit down ? Mr. Hornby — Miss Pringle .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: How d ’ you do ? Everything go off O. K . ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I beg your pardon ?

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Funeral , I mean . Mother went . Regular beano for her .

div.stage: MISS PRINGLE , rather shocked , draws herself up primly , but NORAH ’ S eyes twinkle with amusement at his airy manner .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Really ?

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: You see , she ’ s getting on . I ’ m the child of her old age — Benjamin , don ’ t you know .He turns to Miss Pringle .Benjamin and Sarah , you know .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: I understand perfectly , but it wasn ’ t Sarah .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Wasn ’ t it ? When one of her old friends dies , mother goes to the funeral and says to herself : “ Well , I ’ ve seen her out , anyhow .” Then she comes back and eats muffins for tea . She always eats muffins after she ’ s been to a funeral .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: The maid said you wanted to see about something .

lg.l: That ’ s right , I was forgetting .
If Sarah wasn ’ t
Benjamin ’ s mother , whose mother was she ?

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: If you want to know , I recommend you to read your Bible .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: With much satisfaction .I thought it was a stumper .To NORAH .The fact is , I ’ m going to Canada , and mother told me you ’ d got a brother or something out there .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: A brother , not a something .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: And she said , perhaps you wouldn ’ t mind giving me a letter to him .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I will with pleasure . But I ’ m afraid he won ’ t be much use to you . He ’ s a farmer and he lives miles away from anywhere .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: But I ’ m going in for farming .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Are you ? What on earth for ?

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: I ’ ve jolly well got to do something , and I think farming ’ s about the best thing I can do . One gets a lot of shooting and riding , you know . And then there are tennis parties and dances . And you make a pot of money , there ’ s no doubt about that .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I thought you were in some motor business in London .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Well , I was in a way . But ... I thought you ’ d have heard about it . Mother ’ s been telling everybody . Governor won ’ t speak to me . Altogether things are rotten . I want to get out of this beastly country as quick as I can .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Would you like me to give you the letter at once ?

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: I wish you would .NORAH sits down at an escritoire and begins to write a letter .Fact is , I ’ m broke . I was all right as long as I stuck to bridge . I used to make money on that . Over a thousand a year .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: Horrified .What !

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Playing regularly , you know . If I hadn ’ t been a fool I ’ d have stuck to that . But I got bitten with chemi .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Turning round .With what ?

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Chemin de fer . Never heard of it ? I got in the habit of going to Thornton ’ s . I suppose you never heard of him either . He keeps a gambling hell . Gives you a slap-up supper for nothing , as much pop as you can drink , and changes your cheques like a bird . The result is I ’ ve lost every bob I had , and then Thornton sued me on a cheque I ’ d given him . The Governor forked out , but he says I ’ ve got to go to Canada . I ’ m never going to gamble again , I can tell you that .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , well , that ’ s something .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: You can ’ t make money at chemi . The cagnotte ’ s bound to clear you out in the end . When I come back I ’ m going to stick to bridge . There are always plenty of mugs about , and if you ’ ve got a good head for cards you can ’ t help making an income out of it .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Here is your letter .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Thanks awfully . I daresay I shan ’ t want it , you know . I expect I shall get offered a job the moment I land , but there ’ s no harm having it . I ’ ll be getting along .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Good-bye , then , and good luck .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Good-bye .

div.stage: He shakes hands with NORAH and MISS PRINGLE and goes out .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: Norah , why don ’ t you go to Canada ? Now your brother has a farm of his own I should have thought ....

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Interrupting .My brother ’ s married . He married four years ago .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: You never told me .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I couldn ’ t .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: Why ? Isn ’ t his wife ... isn ’ t his wife nice ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: She was a waitress at a scrubby little hotel in Winnipeg .

sp.speaker: MISS PRINGLE
sp.p: What are you going to do , then ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: It ’ s no good crying over spilt milk . I ’ ll look out for another situation . END OF FIRST ACT

div.head: ACT II

stage.stage: SCENE : The living-room and kitchen on EDWARD MARSH ’ S farm at Dyer , Manitoba . It is a room lined with brown planks , and on the walls in cheap gilt frames are coloured supplements from the Christmas numbers of illustrated papers . Over one door is the head of a moose , and over the other a large kitchen clock . The floor is covered with shiny oil-cloth . In the window are geraniums growing in maple-syrup tins . On one side is a large American stove . There is a dresser of unvarnished deal on which are plates and cups and saucers . They are of the plainest earthenware , and few of them match . There are two American rockers and a number of kitchen chairs . There is a plain kitchen table . On the stove is an enormous kettle and a couple of saucepans . There is a small bookshelf on which are a few tattered novels and some old magazines . The table is set for dinner with a cheap white cloth , none too clean . ED MARSH is sitting at one end , with the remains of a joint of cold beef in front of him , and at the other end is his wife , with a teapot , milk-jug , and sugar-basin . There is a loaf of bread on the table , a large tin containing maple-syrup , and the remains of a milk pudding . NORAH is sitting next to her sister-in-law and beside her is REGINALD HORNBY . Opposite are FRANK TAYLOR and BENJAMIN TROTTER . Dinner is just finished . GERTIE MARSH is a dark little person , with a hard look and a dried-up skin . She is thin and nervous , an active , hard-working woman with a sharp tongue and , outwardly at least , little tenderness . She is dressed in a shirt-waist , a serge skirt , and brown , rather smart high-heeled shoes . She wears a small apron . NORAH wears a white blouse and a green skirt . ED MARSH is a good-natured , easy-going man , with a small moustache and untidy hair . He wears a black flannel shirt , with white lines on it , a black waistcoat , and dark grubby trousers . The others are hired men . FRANK TAYLOR is a tall fellow , strong , with clean-cut features and frank , humorous eyes . He is clean shaven . His movements are slow and he speaks with a marked accent . He is very sure of himself . He wears a dark flannel shirt and a pair of overalls , which have been blue , but are now black and grimy with age . The braces which hold them up announce that they come from Eaton ’ s , Winnipeg . BEN TROTTER is an English labourer , with broken , discoloured teeth , and hair cut very short , with something like a love-lock plastered on his forehead . He is dressed in the same way as FRANK TAYLOR . REGGIE HORNBY ’ S head is still neat and trim , his hair is carefully brushed . His overalls are much newer than the others ’. He wears a flannel shirt which was obviously made in Piccadilly .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Have some more syrup , Reg ?

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: No , thank you .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Has everyone finished ?

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: It looks like it .

div.stage: MARSH pushes back his chair , takes a pouch and pipe from his pocket and lights up . TAYLOR does the same .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: We ’ ll be able to start on the ironing this afternoon .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Very well .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: It was a rare big wash you done this morning by the look of it on the line .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: My arms are just aching .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: When you ’ ve been out in this country a bit longer you ’ ll learn not to wear more things than you can help .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Was there more than my fair share ?

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: You use double the number of stockings than what I do . And everything else is the same .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a smile .Clean but incompetent .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: There ’ s many a true word spoken in jest .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Say , Reg , is it true that when you first come out you asked Ed where the bath-room was ?

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: With a chuckle .That ’ s right . Ed told ’ im there was a river a mile and a ’ alf from ’ ere , an ’ that was the only bath-room ’ e knew .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: One soon gets used to that sort of thing , eh , Reg ?

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Rather . If I saw a bath-room now it would only make me nervous .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Out in B. C . I knew a couple of Englishmen who were baching and the only other people around were Indians . The first two years they was there they wouldn ’ t have anything to do with the Indians because they was so dirty , and after that the Indians wouldn ’ t have anything to do with them .He puts his fingers to his nose to indicate a nasty smell .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What a disgusting story !

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: D ’ you think so ? I rather like it .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You would .

div.stage: He looks at her with a little smile , but does not answer .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Getting up .Are you going to sit there all day , Norah ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Why don ’ t you keep quiet for five minutes ? I guess Norah ’ s not sorry to have a rest after that wash .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: The amount of work Norah did isn ’ t going to tire her much , I reckon .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ m not used to that sort of work yet . It takes it out of me a bit .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: I ’ ve not found out what sort of work you are used to .

div.stage: NORAH gets up and the two women start clearing away the table . MARSH moves into one of the rocking-chairs and smokes .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Give her time to get used to the life , Gertie . You can ’ t expect everything all at once .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: It ’ s always the same with English people . You have to teach them everything .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Well , you didn ’ t have to teach me to propose , Gertie .

div.stage: NORAH takes away things from before TAYLOR and he gets up .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess I ’ m in your way .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Not more than usual , thank you .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Smiling .I guess you ’ ll not be sorry to see the last of me .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I can ’ t honestly say that it makes the least difference to me whether you go or stay .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Now don ’ t start quarrelling , you two .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: When does your train go , Frank ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Half-past three . I ’ ll be starting from here in about an hour .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Reg can go over with you and he ’ ll drive the rig back again .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: All right . I ’ ll go and dress myself in a bit .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: I guess you ’ ll be glad to get back to your own place .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess I shan ’ t be sorry .

div.stage: The clearing away is finished . GERTIE gets a large metal basin and puts it on the table . NORAH fetches the kettle and pours hot water into the basin . They begin washing up .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: I ’ ll do the washing , Norah , and you can dry .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: All right .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: I ’ ve noticed the things aren ’ t half clean when I leave them to you to do .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ m sorry . Why didn ’ t you tell me ?

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: I suppose you never did the washing up in England . Too grand ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I don ’ t suppose anyone would wash up if they could help it . It ’ s not very amusing .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: You always want to be amused .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: No . But I want to be happy .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Well , you ’ ve got a room over your head and a comfortable bed to sleep in , three good meals a day , and plenty to do ; that ’ s all anybody wants to make them happy , I guess .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Oh , lord !

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Turning sharply on him .Well , if you don ’ t like Canada , why did you come out ?

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Rising slowly to his feet .You don ’ t suppose I ’ d have let them send me if I ’ d known what I was in for ? Not much . Up at five in the morning and working in the fields like a navvy till your back feels as if it ’ ud break , and then back again in the afternoon . And the same thing day after day . What was the good of sending me to Harrow and Oxford if that ’ s what I ’ ve got to do all my life ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: You ’ ll get used to it soon enough , Reg . It ’ s a bit hard at first , but when you get your foot in you wouldn ’ t change it for any other life .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: This isn ’ t a country for a man to go to sleep with and wait for something to turn up .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: I wouldn ’ t go back to England now , not for nothing . England ! Eighteen bob a week , that ’ s what I earned , and no prospects . Out of work five months in the year .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What did you do in England ?

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Bricklayer , Miss .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: You needn ’ t call her miss . Norah ’ s her name . You call me Gertie , don ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: What with strikes an ’ bad times you never knew where you was . And the foreman bullying you . I don ’ t know what all . I ’ ad about enough of it , I can tell you . I ’ ve never been out of work since the day I landed . I ’ ve had as much to eat as I wanted and I ’ m saving money . In this country everybody ’ s as good as everybody else .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: If not better .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: In two years I shall be able to set up for myself . Why , there ’ s old man Thompson , up at Pratt , he started as a bricklayer , come from Yorkshire , he did . He ’ s got seven thousand dollars in the bank now .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: You fellows who come out now have a much softer thing on than I did when I first came . In those days they wouldn ’ t have an Englishman , they ’ d have a Galician rather . In Winnipeg , when they advertised in the paper for labour , you ’ d see often as not no English need apply .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Well , it was their own fault . They wouldn ’ t work or anything . They just soaked .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: It was their own fault right enough . This was the dumping ground for all the idlers , drunkards , and scallywags in England . They had the delusion over there that if a man was too big a rotter to do anything at all in England he ’ d only got to be sent out here and he ’ d make a fortune .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess things ain ’ t as bad as that now . They send us a different class . It takes an Englishman two years longer than anybody else to get the hang of things , but when once he tumbles to it he ’ s better than any of them .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: I guess nowadays everyone ’ s glad to see the Englishman make good . When I nearly smashed up three years ago , I had no end of offers to help .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: How did you smash up ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Oh , I had a run of bad luck . One year my crop was frosted and then next year I was hailed out . It wants a good deal of capital to stand up against that .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: That ’ s what happened to me . I was hailed out , and I hadn ’ t got capital , so I just had to hire out .To NORAH .If it hadn ’ t been for that hailstorm you wouldn ’ t have had the pleasure of making my acquaintance .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Ironically .How hollow and empty life would have been without that .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: I wonder you didn ’ t just quit and start out Calgary way .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Well , I ’ d put in two years on my homestead and done a lot of clearing . It seemed kind of silly to lose my rights now . And when you ’ ve been hailed out once the chances are it won ’ t happen again , for some years that is , and by that time I ought to have put a bit by .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What sort of a house have you got ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Well , it ain ’ t what you might call a palace , but it ’ s large enough for two .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Thinking of marrying ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Well , I guess it ’ s kind of lonesome on a farm without a woman . But it ’ s not so easy to find a wife when you ’ re just starting on your own . Canadian girls think twice before taking a farmer .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: They know something , I guess .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Well , you took one , Gertie .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Not because I wanted to , you can be sure of that . I don ’ t know how you got round me .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: I wonder .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: I guess it was because you was kind of helpless , and I didn ’ t know what you ’ d do without me .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: I guess it was love and you couldn ’ t help yourself .

lg.l: I ’ m thinking of going to one of them employment agencies when I get to
Winnipeg and looking the girls over .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Like sheep .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I don ’ t know anythin ’ about sheep . I ’ ve never had to do with sheep .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: And d ’ you think you know anything about women ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess I can tell if they ’ re strong and willing . And so long as they ain ’ t cock-eyed I don ’ t mind taking the rest on trust .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: And what inducement is there for a girl to have you ?

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: That ’ s why he wants to catch ’ em young , when they ’ ve just landed and don ’ t know much .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I ’ ve got my quarter section — a hundred and sixty acres , with seventy of it cleared — and I ’ ve got a shack that I built myself . That ’ s something , ain ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You ’ ve got a home to offer and enough to eat and drink . A girl can get that anywhere . Why , they ’ re simply begging for service .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Some girls like getting married . There ’ s something in the word that appeals to them .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You seem to think a girl would jump at the chance of marrying you .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: She might do worse .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I think you flatter yourself .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I know my job and there ain ’ t too many as can say that . I ’ ve got brains .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What makes you think so ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Well , I can see you ’ re no fool .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: With a chuckle .He put one over on you then , Norah .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Good-humouredly .Because you ’ ve got no use for me , there ’ s no saying but what others may have .

div.stage: GERTIE takes the basin out in order to pour away the water . NORAH goes on drying the crockery .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Of course , there ’ s no accounting for tastes .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I can try , can ’ t I ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: It ’ s very wise of you to go to an agency . A girl ’ s more likely to marry you when she ’ s only seen you once than when she ’ s seen you often .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: With a wink at the others .It seems to make you quite mad , the thought of me marrying .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You wouldn ’ t talk about it like that unless you looked down upon women . Oh , I pity the poor wretched creature who becomes your wife .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess she won ’ t have a bad time when I ’ ve broken her in to my ways .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Are you under the impression you can do that ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Yep .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You ’ re not expecting that there ’ ll be much love lost between you and the girl you — honour with your choice ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: What ’ s love got to do with it ? It ’ s a business proposition .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What !

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I give her board and lodging and the charm of my society . And in return she ’ s got to cook and bake and wash and keep the shack clean and tidy . And if she can do that I ’ ll not be particular what she looks like .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: So long as she ’ s not cock-eyed .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: No , I draw the line at that .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Ironically .I beg your pardon . I didn ’ t know it was a general servant you wanted . You spend a dollar and a half on a marriage licence , and then you don ’ t have to pay any wages . It ’ s a good investment .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You ’ ve got a sharp tongue in your head for a girl , Norah .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Please don ’ t call me Norah .

lg.l: Don ’ t be so silly . It ’ s the custom of the country . Why , they all call me
Ed .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I don ’ t care what the custom of the country is . I ’ m not going to be called Norah by the hired man .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Don ’ t you bother , Ed . I ’ ll call her Miss Marsh if she likes it better .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I should like to see you married to someone who ’ d give you what you deserved . I ’ d like to see your pride humbled . You think yourself very high and mighty , don ’ t you ? I ’ d like to see a woman take you by the heart-strings and wring them till you screamed with pain .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: With a laugh .Norah , how violent you are .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You ’ re overbearing , supercilious , egotistic .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I ’ m not sure as I know what them long words means , but I guess they ain ’ t exactly complimentary .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Furiously .I guess they ain ’ t .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I ’ m sorry for that . I was thinking of offering you the position before I went to the employment agency .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: How dare you speak to me like that !

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Don ’ t fly into a temper , Norah .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: He ’ s got no right to say impudent things to me .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Don ’ t you see he ’ s only having a joke with you ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: He shouldn ’ t joke . He ’ s got no sense of humour .

div.stage: NORAH drops a cup and breaks it , and as this happens GERTIE comes in .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Butter fingers .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ m so sorry .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: You clumsy thing . You ’ re always doing something wrong .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You needn ’ t worry , I ’ ll pay for it .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Who wants you to pay for it ? D ’ you think I can ’ t afford to pay for a cup ? You might say you ’ re sorry — that ’ s all I want you to do .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I said I was sorry .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: No , you didn ’ t .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: I heard her , Gertie .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: She said she was sorry as if she was doing me a favour .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You don ’ t expect me to go down on my knees to you ? The cup ’ s worth twopence .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: It isn ’ t the value I ’ m thinking about , it ’ s the carelessness .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: It ’ s only the third thing I ’ ve broken since I ’ ve been here .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: You can ’ t do anything ; you ’ re more helpless than a child of six . You ’ re all the same , all of you .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You ’ re not going to abuse the whole British nation because I ’ ve broken a cup worth twopence , are you ?

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: And the airs you put on . Condescending isn ’ t the word . It ’ s enough to try the patience of a saint .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Oh , shut up .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: You ’ ve never done a stroke of work in your life , and you come here and think you can teach me everything .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I don ’ t know about that , but I think I can teach you manners .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: How dare you say that ! How dare you ! You come here and I give you a home , you sleep in my blankets and eat my food , and then you insult me .

div.stage: She bursts into tears .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Now then , Gertie , don ’ t cry . Don ’ t be so silly .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Oh , leave me alone . Of course you take her part . You would . It ’ s nothing to you that I ’ ve slaved for you for three years . As soon as she comes along and plays the lady ....

div.stage: She hurries out of the room . MARSH hesitates for a moment and then follows his wife . There is a momentary pause .

lg.l: I reckon I might be cleaning myself . Time ’ s getting on . You ’ re coming ,
Ben ?

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Yes , I ’ m coming . I suppose you ’ ll take the mare ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Yep . That ’ s what Ed said this morning .

div.stage: They go out . NORAH is left alone with REGGIE HORNBY .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: With a little smile .Well , are you enjoying the land of promise as much as you said I should ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: We ’ ve both made our bed and we must lie in it .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: D ’ you remember that afternoon at Miss Wickham ’ s when I came for a letter to your brother ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I hadn ’ t much intention of coming to Canada then .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: I don ’ t mind telling you that I mean to get back to England the very first opportunity I get . I ’ m willing to give away my share of the White Man ’ s Burden with a packet of chewing gum .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Smiling .You prefer the Effete East ?

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Rather . Give me the degrading influence of a decadent civilisation every time .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Your father will be pleased to see you , won ’ t he ?

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: I don ’ t think . Of course , I was a damned fool ever to leave Winnipeg .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I understand you didn ’ t till you were forced to .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Your brother behaved like a perfect brick . I sent him on your letter and told him I was up against it — d ’ you know I hadn ’ t got a bob ? I was jolly glad to earn half a dollar by digging a pit in a man ’ s garden . Bit thick , you know .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Laughing .I can see you .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Your brother sent me my fare to come here and told me I could do the chores . I didn ’ t know what they were . I found out it was doing all the jobs that it wasn ’ t anybody else ’ s job to do . And they call it God ’ s own country .

div.stage: Meanwhile NORAH has put a couple of irons on the stove and now she gets the board . It is rather heavy for her .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I think you ’ re falling into the ways very well .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: What makes you think that ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a smile .You can sit by and smoke your pipe , and watch me carry the ironing board about .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Without moving .D ’ you want me to help you ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: No .... It would remind me of home .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: I suppose I shall have to stick it out at least a year , unless I can humbug the mater into sending me enough money to get home with .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: She won ’ t send you a penny if she ’ s wise .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Wouldn ’ t you chuck it if you could ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a flash of spirit .And acknowledge myself beaten ?There is a short pause .You don ’ t know what I went through before I came here . I tried to get another position as lady ’ s companion . I answered advertisements . I hung about the agent ’ s offices .... Two people offered to take me without a salary . One woman suggested ten shillings a week and my lunch . She expected me to find myself a room , clothes , breakfast and supper on ten shillings a week . That settled me . I wrote to Eddie and said I was coming . When I ’ d paid my fare I had eight pounds in the world . That ’ s the result of ten years ’ work as lady ’ s companion . When he came to meet me at the station at Dyer ....

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Don ’ t call it a station , call it a depôt .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: My whole fortune consisted of seven dollars and thirty-five cents .

div.stage: MARSH comes in and gives HORNBY a glance .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: What about that wood you were splitting , Reg ? You ’ d better be getting on with it .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Oh , lord , is there no rest for the wicked ?

div.stage: He gets up slowly and saunters lazily to the door .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Don ’ t hurry yourself , will you ?

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Brilliant sarcasm is just flying about the house to-day .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: That ’ s about the toughest nut I ’ ve ever been set to crack . Why on earth did you give him a letter to me ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: He asked me . I couldn ’ t very well say no .

div.stage: Throughout the scene NORAH goes on ironing things which she takes from a pile of washing in the basket .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: I can ’ t make out what people are up to in the Old Country . They think that if a man is too big a rotter to do anything at all in England they ’ ve only got to send him out here and he ’ ll make a fortune .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: He may improve .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: With a look at NORAH .You ’ ve thoroughly upset Gertie .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: She ’ s very easily upset , isn ’ t she ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: It ’ s only since you came that things haven ’ t gone right . We never used to have scenes .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Do you blame me ? I came prepared to like her and help her . She met all my advances with suspicion .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: She thinks you look down upon her . You ought to remember that she never had your opportunities . She ’ s earned her own living from the time she was thirteen . You can ’ t expect in her the refinements of a woman who ’ s led the protected life that you have .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I haven ’ t said a word that could be turned into the least suggestion of disapproval of anything she did .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: My dear , your whole manner has expressed disapproval . You won ’ t do things in the way we do them . After all , the way you lived in Tunbridge Wells isn ’ t the only way people can live . Our ways suit us , and when you live amongst us you must adopt them .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: She never gave me a chance to learn them . She treated me with suspicion and enmity from the very first day I came here . When she sneered at me because I talked of a station instead of a depôt , of course I went on talking of a station . Because I prefer to drink water with my meals instead of strong tea she said I was putting on side .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Why can ’ t you humour her ? You see , you ’ ve got to take the blame for all the English people who came here in the past and were lazy , worthless , and supercilious . They called us Colonials and turned up their noses at us . What d ’ you expect us to do ? Say , “ Thank you very much , sir ; we know we ’ re not worthy to black your boots ; and don ’ t bother to work — it ’ ll be a pleasure for us to give you money ”? It ’ s no good blinking the fact , there was a great prejudice against the English , but it ’ s giving way now , and every sensible man and woman who comes out can do something to destroy it .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a shrug of the shoulders .If you ’ re tired of having me here I can go back to Winnipeg . I shan ’ t have any difficulty in finding something to do .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Good lord , I don ’ t want you to go . I like having you here , and it ’ s company for Gertie . And you know , jobs aren ’ t so easy to find as you think , especially now the winter ’ s coming on . Everyone wants a job in the city .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What d ’ you want me to do ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Well , you ’ ve got to live with Gertie . Why can ’ t you make the best of things and meet her half way ? You might make allowances for her even if you think her unreasonable .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ ll have a try .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: I think you ought to apologise for what you said to her just now .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ? I ’ ve got nothing to apologise for . She drove me to distraction .

div.stage: There is a moment ’ s pause . MARSH , now that he has come to the object of all he has been saying , is a little embarrassed .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: She says she won ’ t speak to you again until you beg her pardon .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Does she look upon that as a great hardship ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: My dear , we ’ re twelve miles from the nearest store . We ’ re thrown upon one another through the whole of the winter . Last year there was a bad blizzard , and for six weeks we didn ’ t see a soul outside the farm . Unless we learn to put up with one another ’ s whims life becomes a perfect hell .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You can go on talking all night , Eddie — I ’ ll never apologise . Time after time when she sneered at me till my blood boiled . I ’ ve kept my temper . She deserved ten times more than I said . D ’ you think I ’ m going to knuckle under to a woman like that ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Remember she ’ s my wife , Norah .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Why didn ’ t you marry a lady ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: What the dickens d ’ you think is the use of being a lady out here ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You ’ ve degenerated since you left England .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Now , look here , my dear , I ’ ll just tell you what Gertie did for me . She was a waitress in Winnipeg at the Minnedosa Hotel , and she was making money . She knew what the life was on a farm , much harder than anything she ’ d been used to in the city , but she accepted all the hardship of it , and the monotony — because she loved me .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: She thought it a good match . You were a gentleman .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Fiddledidee . She had the chance of much better men than me .... And when I lost my harvest two years running , d ’ you know what she did ? She went back to the hotel in Winnipeg for the winter so as to carry things on till the next harvest . And at the end of the winter she gave me every cent she ’ d earned to pay the interest of my mortgage and the instalments on the machinery .

div.stage: There is a pause .

lg.l: Very well , I ’ ll apologise . But leave me alone with her . I — I don ’ t think
I could do it before anyone else .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: All right . I ’ ll go and tell her .

div.stage: He goes out . NORAH is left alone with her thoughts . In a moment GERTIE comes back , followed by MARSH .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Trying to take things lightly .I ’ ve been getting on with the ironing .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Have you ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a smile .That is one of the few things I can do all right .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Any child can iron .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Well , I ’ ll be going down to the shed .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Turning to him quickly .What for ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: I want to see about mending that door . It hasn ’ t been closing properly .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: I thought Norah had something to say to me .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: That ’ s what I ’ m going to leave you alone for .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: I like that . She insults me before everybody and then when she ’ s going to apologise it ’ s got to be private . No , thank you .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What d ’ you mean , Gertie ?

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: You sent Ed in to tell me you was going to apologise for what you ’ d said , didn ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: For peace and quietness .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Well , what you said was before the men , and it ’ s before the men you must say you ’ re sorry .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: How can you ask me to do such a thing !

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Don ’ t be rough on her , Gertie . No one likes apologising .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: People who don ’ t like apologising should keep a better lookout on their tongue .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: It can ’ t do you any good to have her eat humble pie before the men .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Perhaps not , but it ’ ll do her good .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Gertie , don ’ t be cruel . I ’ m sorry if I lost my temper just now and said anything that hurt you . Please don ’ t make me humiliate myself before the others .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: I ’ ve made up my mind , so it ’ s no good talking .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Don ’ t you see it ’ s bad enough to beg your pardon before Eddie ?

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Irritably .Why don ’ t you call him Ed like the rest of us ? Eddie sounds so soppy .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ ve called him Eddie all my life .... It ’ s what his mother called him .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: You do everything you can to make yourself different from all of us .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: No , I don ’ t , I promise you I don ’ t . Why won ’ t you give me any credit for trying to do my best to please you ?

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: That ’ s neither here nor there . Go and fetch the men , Ed , and then I ’ ll hear what she ’ s got to say .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: No , I won ’ t , I won ’ t , I won ’ t . You drive me too far .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: You won ’ t beg my pardon ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Beside herself .I said I could teach you manners . I made a mistake , I couldn ’ t teach you manners . One can ’ t make a silk purse out of a sow ’ s ear .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Sharply .Shut up , Norah .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Now you must make her , Ed .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: I ’ m sick to death of the pair of you .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: I ’ m your wife , and I ’ m going to be mistress of this house .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: It ’ s horrible to make her eat humble pie before three strange men . You ’ ve got no right to ask her to do a thing like that .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Furiously .Are you taking her part ? What ’ s come over you since she come here ? You ’ re not the same to me as you used to be . Why did she come here and get between us ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: I haven ’ t done anything .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Haven ’ t I been a good wife to you ? Have you ever had any complaint to make about me ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: You know I haven ’ t .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: As soon as your sister comes along you let me be insulted . You don ’ t say a word to defend me .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: With a grim smile .Darling , you ’ ve said a good many to defend yourself .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: I ’ m sick and tired of being put upon . You must choose between us .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: What on earth d ’ you mean ?

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: If you don ’ t make her apologise right now before the hired men I ’ m quit of you .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: I can ’ t make her apologise if she won ’ t .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Then let her quit .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , I wish I could . I wish to God I could .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: You know she can ’ t do that . There ’ s nowhere she can go . I ’ ve offered her a home . You were quite willing when I suggested having her here .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: I was willing because I thought she ’ d make herself useful . We can ’ t afford to feed folks as don ’ t earn their keep . We have to work for our money , we do .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I didn ’ t know you grudged me the little I eat . I wonder if I should if I were in your place .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Look here , it ’ s no good talking . I ’ m not going to turn her out . As long as she wants a home the farm ’ s open to her . And she ’ s welcome to everything I ’ ve got .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Then you choose her ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Irritably .I don ’ t know what you ’ re talking about .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: I said you ’ d got to choose between us . Very well . Let her stay . I earned my living before , and I can earn it again . I ’ m going .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Don ’ t talk such nonsense .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: You think I don ’ t mean it ? D ’ you think I ’ m going to stay here and be put upon ? Why should I ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Don ’ t you — love me any more ?

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Haven ’ t I shown that I love you ? Have you forgotten , Ed ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: We ’ ve gone through so much together , darling .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Hesitatingly .Yes , we have that .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Won ’ t you forgive her ?

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: No , I can ’ t . You ’ re a man , you don ’ t understand . If she won ’ t apologise , either she must go or I shall .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: I can ’ t lose you , Gertie . What should I do without you ?

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: I guess you know me well enough by now . When I say a thing I do it .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Eddie .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Ill at ease .After all , she ’ s my wife . If it weren ’ t for her I should be hiring out now at forty dollars a month .

div.stage: NORAH hesitates for a moment , then she makes up her mind .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Hoarsely .Very well , I ’ ll do what you want .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: You do insist on it , Gertie ?

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Of course I do .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: I ’ ll go and call the men .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Frank Taylor needn ’ t come , need he ?

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: He ’ s going away to-day . It can ’ t much matter about him , surely .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Why are you so particular about it , then ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: The others are English . He ’ ll like to see me humiliated . He looks upon women as dirt . He ’ s .... Oh , I don ’ t know , but not before him .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: It ’ ll do you a world of good to be taken down a peg or two , my lady .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , how heartless — how cruel .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Go on , Ed — I want to get on with my work .

div.stage: MARSH hesitates a moment , then shrugs his shoulders and goes out .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Passionately .Why do you humiliate me like this ?

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: You came here and thought you knew everything , I guess . You didn ’ t know who you ’ d got to deal with .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I was a stranger and homeless . If you ’ d had any kindness you wouldn ’ t have treated me so . I wanted to be fond of you .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: You despised me before you ever saw me .

div.stage: NORAH covers her eyes for a moment with both hands , and then forces herself to make another appeal .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , Gertie , can ’ t we be friends ? Can ’ t we let bygones be bygones and start afresh ? We ’ re both fond of Eddie . He ’ s your husband and you love him , and he ’ s the only relation I have in the world . Won ’ t you let me be a real sister to you ?

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: It ’ s rather late to say all that now .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: But it ’ s not too late , is it ? I don ’ t know what I do that irritates you . I can see how competent you are , and I admire you so much . I know how splendid you ’ ve been with Eddie , and how you ’ ve stuck to him through thick and thin . You ’ ve done everything for him .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Breaking in violently .Oh , don ’ t go on patronising me . I shall go crazy .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Astounded .Patronising you ?

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: You talk to me as if I was a naughty child . You might be a school teacher .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: It seems perfectly hopeless .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Even when you ’ re begging my pardon you put on airs . You ask me to forgive you as if you was doing me a favour .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a chuckle .I must have a very unfortunate manner .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Furiously .Don ’ t laugh at me .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Don ’ t make yourself ridiculous , then .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: D ’ you think I shall ever forget what you wrote to Ed before I married him ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Looking at her quickly .I don ’ t know what you mean .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Don ’ t you ? You told him it would be a disgrace if he married me . He was a gentleman and I .... Oh , you spread yourself out .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: He oughtn ’ t to have shown you the letter .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: He was dotty about me .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I had a perfect right to try and prevent the marriage before it took place . But after it happened I only wanted to make the best of it . If you had a grudge against me why did you let me come here ?

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Ed wanted it , and it was lonely enough sometimes with the men away all day and no one to talk to . I thought you ’ d be company for me .... I can ’ t bear it when Ed talks to you about the Old Country and people I don ’ t know nothing about .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Surprised .Are you jealous ?

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: It ’ s my house and I ’ m mistress here . I won ’ t be put upon . What did you want to come here for , upsetting everybody ? Till you come I never had a word with Ed . Oh , I hate you , I hate you .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Gertie .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: You ’ ve given me a chance and I ’ m going to take it . I ’ m going to take you down a peg or two .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You ’ re doing all you can to drive me away from here .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: You don ’ t think it ’ s much catch to have you . You talk of getting a job — you couldn ’ t get one . I know something about that , my girl . You ! You can do nothing .... Here they are . Now take your medicine .

div.stage: ED MARSH comes in , followed by TROTTER and FRANK TAYLOR . FRANK has taken off his overalls .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
