sp.p: Where ’ s Reg ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: He ’ s just coming .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Do they know what they ’ re here for ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: No , I didn ’ t tell them .

div.stage: HORNBY comes in .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Norah insulted me a while ago before all of you , and I guess she wants to apologise .

lg.l: If you told me it was that , Ed , you wanted me to come here for , I reckon
I ’ d have told you to go to hell .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I ’ ve got other things to do beside bothering my head about women ’ s quarrels .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , I beg your pardon , I thought it was some kindly feeling in you .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Go on , Norah , we ’ re waiting .

div.stage: NORAH hesitates a moment and then takes her courage in both hands .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ m sorry I was rude to you , Gertie . I apologise for what I said .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: With a quiet smile .You didn ’ t find that very easy to say , I reckon .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: There ’ s nothing more to be said , is there ?

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: I ’ m quite satisfied .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: We ’ d better get back to work , then .

div.stage: The men turn to go .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Let this be a lesson to you , my girl .

div.stage: NORAH starts at the words . It is the last straw .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Frank , will you wait a minute ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: A little surprised .Sure . What can I do for you ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ ve understood that I ’ m not wanted here . I ’ m in the way . You said just now you wanted a woman to cook and bake for you , wash and mend your clothes , and keep your shack clean and tidy . Will I do ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Rather amused .Sure .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Horrified .Norah .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a twinkle in her eye .I ’ m afraid you ’ ll have to marry me .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess it would be more respectable .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Norah , you can ’ t mean it . You ’ re in a temper . See here , Frank , you mustn ’ t pay any attention to her .

sp.speaker: GERTIE
sp.p: Shameless , that ’ s what I call it .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Why ? He wants a woman to look after him . He practically proposed to me half an hour ago . Didn ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Practically .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: I ’ m bound to say I ’ ve never heard a proposal refused so emphatically .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: You ’ ve been like cat and dog with Frank ever since you came . My dear , you don ’ t know what you ’ re in for .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: If he ’ s willing to risk it , I am .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Looking at her gravely .It ain ’ t an easy life you ’ re coming to . This farm ’ s a palace compared with my shack .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ m not wanted here , and you say you want me . If you ’ ll take me , I ’ ll come .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I ’ ll take you all right . When will you be ready ? Will an hour do for you ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Suddenly panic-stricken .An hour ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Why , yes , then we can catch the three-thirty into Winnipeg . You can go to the Y. W. C. A . for the night and we ’ ll be buckled up in the morning .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You ’ re in a great hurry .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I suppose you meant it ? You weren ’ t just pulling a bluff ?

div.stage: NORAH hesitates for a moment and they look at one another .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I shall be ready in an hour . END OF THE SECOND ACT

div.head: ACT III

stage.stage: SCENE : FRANK TAYLOR ’ S shack at Prentice , Manitoba . It is a low log cabin , consisting of two rooms . The scene is the living-room . There is a door at the back towards the left-hand side , and on the right is another door that leads into the bedroom . A very small low window at the back . There is a stove on the left , with a long chimney . On the walls , untidily tacked up , are pictures cut out of the illustrated papers . Hanging on a nail is a Cariboo coat . On a shelf beside the stove are the few pots and pans that FRANK TAYLOR possesses . They are battered and much used . There is a broom in the corner . The furniture consists of a rocking-chair , worn with use and shabby , a table roughly made by TAYLOR himself from packing-cases , one kitchen chair and two or three packing-cases used as stools . On another shelf are maple-syrup tins , in which groceries are kept . In one corner there is an old suit-case , locally known as a grip , and a heap of old clothes ; in another corner is a pile of tattered magazines and numbers of the Winnipeg Free Press . The shack has an untidy , comfortless , bedraggled air .

When the curtain rises the scene is dark and empty . There is a faint glimmer of light through the window . The night is bright and starry . There is a slight noise of a rig being driven up outside , and then voices are heard .

sp.speaker: SHARP
sp.p: Woa there ! Woa !

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: A tidy pull , that last bit . Trail ’ s very bad .

sp.speaker: SHARP
sp.p: Stop still , you brute .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess she wants to get home .

div.stage: Now comes the sound of a key being put into the lock . It is turned noisily and the door is opened wide . A rig stands outside and SHARP is seen still seated holding the reins . NORAH has just got down . Tied on the back of the rig are NORAH ’ S trunk and TAYLOR ’ S grip . There is a glimpse of the prairie and the bright Canadian night . TAYLOR comes in . He is wearing a waterproof coat lined with sheepskin , a dark , roughly cut suit of some coarse blue material , and a broad-brimmed , flat-crowned hat .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Wait a minute , and I ’ ll light the lamp .He strikes a match and looks round .Where in hell has it got to ? The shack ’ s about two foot by three , and I ’ m blamed if I can ever find a darned thing .

sp.speaker: SHARP
sp.p: I ’ ll give you a hand with that trunk .

div.stage: As he speaks he begins to get down . TAYLOR finds the lamp and lights it .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I ’ ll come and help you if you ’ ll wait a bit . Come in , Norah .

sp.speaker: SHARP
sp.p: Woa there !

div.stage: NORAH comes in . She has on a hat and coat . She carries a string bag in which there is a number of parcels .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ m quite stiff after that long drive .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Are you cold ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: No , not a bit . I was well wrapped up .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess it ’ s freezing . But it ’ s your first winter and you won ’ t feel the cold like we do .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Putting down her bag .I ’ ll bring some of the things in .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Don ’ t touch the trunk , it ’ s too heavy for you .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ m as strong as a horse .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Don ’ t touch it .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a smile .I won ’ t .

div.stage: He goes out and takes more parcels out of the rig and comes in with them .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: We can all do with a cup of tea . Just have a look at the stove . It won ’ t take two shakes to light a fire .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: It seems hardly worth while . It ’ s so late .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Cheerily .Light the fire , my girl , and don ’ t talk about it .

div.stage: He goes out and is seen helping SHARP to unfasten the trunk . NORAH , getting down on her knees , rakes out the ashes from the stove . TAYLOR and SHARP bring the box in between them . SHARP is a rough-looking man of forty . He has been a non-commissioned officer in an English regiment , and has still something of a soldier ’ s look .

sp.speaker: SHARP
sp.p: This trunk of yours isn ’ t what you might call light , Mrs. Taylor .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: It contains all I own in the world .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess it don ’ t do that . Since this morning you own a half share in a hundred and sixty acres of as good land as there is in Manitoba and a mighty fine shack .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: To say nothing of a husband .

sp.speaker: SHARP
sp.p: Where d ’ you want this put ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: It ’ ud better go in the next room right away , or we shall be falling over it .

div.stage: They carry the trunk into the bedroom . NORAH gets up from her knees , goes over to a pile of logs by the stove , and takes two or three and some of the newspapers . The men come in again .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Here , you won ’ t be able to light a fire with logs like that . Where ’ s that darned axe ?He glances round and sees it by the logs . He takes a couple and splits them .I guess you ’ ll have plenty to do getting the shack tidy .SHARP brings in TAYLOR ’ S grip and his gun .Now , that ’ s real good of you , Sid .

sp.speaker: SHARP
sp.p: Get any shooting down at Dyer , Frank ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: There was a rare lot of prairie chickens around , but I didn ’ t get out more than a couple of days .

sp.speaker: SHARP
sp.p: Well , I ’ ll be getting back home now .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Oh , stay and have a cup of tea , won ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: SHARP
sp.p: I don ’ t think I will . It ’ s getting late and the mare ’ ll get cold .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Put her in the shed .

sp.speaker: SHARP
sp.p: No , I think I ’ ll be toddling . My missus says I was to give you her compliments , Mrs. Taylor , and she ’ ll be round to-morrow to see if there ’ s anything you want .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: That ’ s very kind of her . Thank you very much .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Sid lives where you saw that light just about a mile from here , Norah . Mrs. Sharp ’ ll be able to help you a lot at first .

sp.speaker: SHARP
sp.p: Oh , well , we ’ ve been here for thirteen years , and we know the way of the country by now .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Norah ’ s about as green as a new dollar bill , I guess .

sp.speaker: SHARP
sp.p: There ’ s a lot you can ’ t be expected to know at first . I ’ ll say good-night , then , and good luck .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Well , good-night then , Sid , if you won ’ t stay , and it was real good of you to come and fetch us in the rig .

sp.speaker: SHARP
sp.p: Oh , that ’ s all right . Good-night to you , Mrs. Taylor .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Good-night .

div.stage: SHARP goes out , gets on the rig , and drives away .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess it must seem funny to you to hear him call you Mrs. Taylor , eh ?

div.stage: NORAH gives him a quick look , and represses a little shudder .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: How are you getting on with that fire ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: All right .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess I ’ ll get some water .

div.stage: He takes a pail and goes out . He is heard pumping . NORAH gets up , lifts the lamp so as to see better , and looks round . She is pale , and has a frightened look . She does not hear FRANK come in , and starts violently when he speaks to her .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Having a look at the shack ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Putting the lamp down .How you startled me .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: What d ’ you think of it ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I don ’ t know .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I built it with my own hands . Every one of them logs was a tree I cut down myself . You wait till the morning and I ’ ll show you how they ’ re joined together at the corners . There ’ s some neat work there , my girl , I guess .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Here ’ s the kettle .

div.stage: He pours water into it from the pail , and she puts the kettle on the stove .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You ’ ll find some tea in one of them tins on the shelf . Leastways there was some there when I come away . I guess you ’ re hungry .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I don ’ t think I am , very . I ate a very good supper in the train .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I ’ m glad you call that a good supper . I guess I could wrap up the amount you ate in a postal stamp .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Smiling .I haven ’ t a very large appetite .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I have . Where ’ s the loaf we got in Winnipeg this afternoon ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ ll get it .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: And the butter . You ’ ll bake to-morrow , I reckon .

div.stage: NORAH gets a loaf and a piece of butter out of the string bag she brought in with her . She puts them on the table .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Shall I cut you some ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Yep .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Please .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Please what ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a smile .Yes , please .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Oh !

div.stage: He gives her a look , and she , a quiet smile on her face , cuts two or three pieces of bread and butter . Then she gets tea out of the tin and puts it in a teapot .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess you ’ d better take your hat and coat off .

div.stage: NORAH does so without answering .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You ain ’ t terribly talkative for a woman , my girl .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I haven ’ t got anything to say at the moment .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Well , I guess it ’ s better to have a wife as talks too little than a wife as talks too much .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With her tongue in her cheek .I suppose absolute perfection is rare — in women , poor wretches .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: What ’ s that ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I was only amusing myself with a reflection .

div.stage: TAYLOR takes off his coat and appears in a grey sweater . He sits down in the rocking chair .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess there ’ s no place like home . You get a bit fed up with hiring out . Ed was O. K ., I reckon , but it ain ’ t like being your own boss .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Pointing .What ’ s through there ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Oh , that ’ s the bedroom . Like to have a look ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: When I built the shack I fixed it up so as it would do when I got married . Sid Sharp asked me what in hell I wanted to divide it up in half for , but I guess women like little luxuries like that .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Like what ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Like having a room to sleep in and a room to live in .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Here ’ s the bread and butter . Will you have some syrup ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Sure .

div.stage: He gets up and sits down at the table .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: That water ought to be boiling by now . What about milk ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: That ’ s one of the things you ’ ll have to do without till I can afford to buy a cow .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I can ’ t drink tea without milk .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You try . Say , can you milk a cow ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ? No .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Then it ’ s just as well I ain ’ t got one .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You ’ re a philosopher .

div.stage: She lifts the cover off the kettle and looks at it , then pours some water into the teapot , and sets it down on the table .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Is there a candle ? I ’ ll just get one or two things out of my box .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Ain ’ t you going to sit down and have a cup of tea ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I don ’ t want any , thanks .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Sit down , my girl .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Smiling .Because I tell you to .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Quite pleasantly .I don ’ t think you ’ d better tell me to do things .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Then I ask you . You ain ’ t going to refuse the first favour I ’ ve asked you ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a pretty smile .Of course not .She sits down .There .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Now pour out my tea for me , will you ?He watches her do it .It is rum seeing my wife sitting down at my table and pouring out tea for me .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Is it pleasant ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Sure . Now have some yourself , my girl . You ’ ll soon get used to drinking it without milk . And I guess you ’ ll be able to get some to-morrow from Mrs. Sharp .

div.stage: NORAH pours herself out some tea .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I had a sort of a feeling I wanted you and me to have the first meal together in your new home . Just take a bit of the bread and butter .

div.stage: He passes over to her a slice and , smiling , she cuts a little piece off and eats it .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: We ain ’ t lost much time , I guess . Why , it ’ s only yesterday you told me not to call you Norah .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: That was very silly of me . I was in a temper .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: And now we ’ re man and wife .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Married in haste with a vengeance .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Ain ’ t you a bit scared ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ? What of ? You ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: With Ed on t ’ other side of Winnipeg , he might just as well be in the Old Country for all the good he can be to you . You might be a bit scared to find yourself alone with a man you don ’ t know .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ m not nervous .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Good for you .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You did give me a fright , though . When I asked you if you ’ d take me , I suppose it was only about fifteen seconds before you answered , but it seemed like ten minutes . I thought you might refuse .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I was thinking .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Smiling .Counting up my good points and setting them against the bad ones ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: No , I was thinking you wouldn ’ t have asked me like that if you hadn ’ t — despised me .

div.stage: NORAH , a little taken aback , gives him a quick look , but she tries to pass it off lightly .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I don ’ t know what makes you think that .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Well , I don ’ t know how you could have put it more plainly that my name was mud .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Why didn ’ t you refuse , then ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess I ’ m not a nervous fellow , either .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a twinkle in her eye .And women are scarce in Manitoba .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I always fancied an Englishwoman . They make the best wives when they ’ ve been licked into shape .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Frankly amused .Are you proposing to attempt that operation on me ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You ’ re clever . I guess a hint or two is about all you ’ ll want .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: It embarrasses me when you pay me compliments .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I ’ ll take you round and show you the land to-morrow . I ain ’ t done all the clearing yet , so there ’ ll be plenty of work for the winter . I want to have a hundred acres to sow next year . And then if I get a good crop I ’ ve a mind to take another quarter . You can ’ t make it pay really without you ’ ve got half a section . And it ’ s a tough proposition when you ain ’ t got capital .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I didn ’ t think I was marrying a millionaire .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Never mind , my girl , you shan ’ t live in a shack long , I promise you . It ’ s the greatest country in the world . We only want three good crops and you shall have a brick house same as you lived in at home .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I wonder what they ’ re doing in England now .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Well , I guess they ’ re asleep .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: When I think of England I always think of it at tea-time .She looks at the tea-things they have just used .Miss Wickham had a beautiful old silver teapot — George II .— and she was awfully proud of it . And she was very proud of her tea-set — it was old Worcester — and she wouldn ’ t let anyone wash the things but .... And two or three times a week an old Indian judge came in to tea , and he used to talk to me about the East — oh , why did you make me think of it all ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: The past is dead and gone , my girl . We ’ ve got the future .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Paying no attention to his words .One never knows when one ’ s well off , does one ? It ’ s madness to think of what ’ s gone for ever .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I wish we ’ d got a drop of liquor here so as we could drink one another ’ s health . But as we ain ’ t you ’ d better give me a kiss instead .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Lightly .I ’ m not very fond of kissing .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: With a smile .It ain ’ t generally an acquired taste , but I guess you ’ re peculiar .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: It looks like it .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Come , my girl , you didn ’ t even kiss me after we was married .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: In a perfectly friendly way .Isn ’ t a hint enough for you ? Why do you force me to say everything in so many words ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: It seems to me it wants a few words to make it plain when a woman refuses to give her husband a kiss .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Do sit down , there ’ s a good fellow , and I ’ ll tell you one or two things .

lg.l: That ’ s terribly kind of you .
lg.stage: He sinks back into the rocking-chair .
lg.l: Have you any choice of seats ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You ’ ve taken the only one that ’ s tolerably comfortable . I think there ’ s nothing to choose between the others .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Nothing .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I think we ’ d better fix things up before we go any further .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Sure .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You gave me to understand very plainly that you wanted a wife in order to get a general servant without having to pay her wages . Wages are high in Canada .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: That was the way you put it .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Baching isn ’ t very comfortable .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Not very .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You wanted someone to cook and bake for you , wash , sweep , and mend . I offered to come and do all that . It never struck me for an instant that there was any possibility of your expecting anything else of me .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Then you ’ re a damned fool , my girl .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Firing up .D ’ you mind not saying things like that to me ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Good-humouredly .I guess I shall have to say a good many things like that before we ’ ve done .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I asked you to marry me only because I couldn ’ t stay in the shack without .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess you asked me to marry you because you was in a hell of a temper . You wanted to get away from Ed ’ s farm right then , and you didn ’ t care what you did so long as you quit . But you was darned sorry for what you ’ d done by the time you ’ d packed your box .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Frigidly .What makes you think that ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Why , when you come back in the kitchen you was as white as a sheet . You wanted to say you ’ d changed your mind , but your darned pride wouldn ’ t let you .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I wouldn ’ t have stayed on in that house for anything in the world .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: And this morning , when I called for you at the Y. W. C. A ., you wanted to say you wouldn ’ t marry me . You tried to speak the words , but they wouldn ’ t come . When you shook hands with me your hand was like ice .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I was nervous for a moment . After all , one isn ’ t married every day of one ’ s life , is one ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: If I hadn ’ t shown you the licence and the ring , I guess you wouldn ’ t have done it . You hadn ’ t the nerve to back out of it then .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I hadn ’ t slept a wink all night . I kept on turning it over in my mind . I was frightened at what I ’ d done . But I didn ’ t know a soul in Winnipeg . I hadn ’ t anywhere to go . I had four dollars in my pocket . I had to go through with it .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You took pretty good stock of me in the train on the way here , I guess .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Recovering herself .What makes you think so ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Well , I felt you was looking at me a good deal . It wasn ’ t hard to see that you was turning me over in your mind . What conclusion did you come to ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You see , I lived all those years with an old lady . I know very little about men .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guessed that .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I came to the conclusion that you were a decent fellow . I thought you would be kind to me .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Bouquets are just flying around . Have you got anything more to say to me ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Then just get me my pouch , will you ? I guess it ’ s in the pocket of my coat .

div.stage: She hesitates a moment , looks at him , then gets it .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Here you are .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: With his tongue in his cheek .I thought you was going to tell me I could darned well get it myself .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I don ’ t very much like being ordered about .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You never paid much attention to me till to-day , I reckon .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I was always polite to you .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Very . But I was the hired man , and you never let me forget it . You thought yourself a darned sight better than me because you could play the piano and speak French . But we ain ’ t got a piano , and there ain ’ t anyone as speaks French nearer than Winnipeg .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What are you driving at ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Parlour tricks ain ’ t much good on the prairie . They ’ re like dollar bills up in Hudson Bay . Tobacco ’ s the only thing you can trade with an Esquimaux . You can ’ t cook very well , you don ’ t know how to milk a cow — why , you can ’ t even harness a horse .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Are you regretting your bargain already ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: No , I guess I can teach you . But if I was you I wouldn ’ t put on any frills . We shall get along O. K ., I guess , when we ’ ve shaken down .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You ’ ll find I ’ m perfectly capable of taking care of myself .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Ignoring the remark .When two people live together in a shack there ’ s got to be a deal of give and take on both sides . As long as you do what I tell you you ’ ll be all right .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a smile .It ’ s unfortunate that when anyone tells me to do a thing I have an irresistible desire not to do it .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess I tumbled to that . You must get over it .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You ’ ve talked to me once or twice in a way I don ’ t like . I think we shall get on better if you ask me to do things .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Don ’ t forget that I can make you do them .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Amused .How ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Well , I ’ m stronger than you are .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: A man can hardly use force in his dealings with a woman .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Oh ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You seem surprised .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: What ’ s going to prevent him ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a little laugh .Don ’ t be so silly .

div.stage: He gives her a look and then smiles quietly to himself .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Well , I ’ m going to unpack my grip .Pointing to the tea-things .Wash up them things .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a slight shrug of the shoulders .I ’ ll wash them up in the morning .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Wash ’ em up now , my girl . You ’ ll find the only way to keep things clean is to wash ’ em the moment you ’ ve done with them .

div.stage: NORAH looks at him with a slight smile on her face , but does not move .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Did you hear what I said ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I did .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Why don ’ t you do as I tell you ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Smiling .Because I don ’ t choose .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You ain ’ t taken long to try it out .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: They say there ’ s no time like the present .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Are you going to wash up them things ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: No .

div.stage: He looks at her for a moment , then gets up , pours water into a pail and puts a ragged dishcloth on the table .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Are you going to wash up them things ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: D ’ you want me to make you ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: How can you do that ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I ’ ll show you .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ ll just get out these rugs , shall I ? I expect it gets very cold towards morning .

div.stage: She gets up and goes over to a holdall and begins unstrapping it .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Norah .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Come here .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Because I tell you .

div.stage: She looks at him , but does not move . He goes over to her and is about to seize her wrist .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You daren ’ t touch me .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Who told you that ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Have you forgotten that I ’ m a woman ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: No , I haven ’ t . That ’ s why I ’ m going to make you do as I tell you . If you was a man I mightn ’ t be able to . Come now .

div.stage: He makes a movement to take her by the arm , but she slips away from him and quickly boxes his ears . He stops .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: That was a darned silly thing to do .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What did you expect ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I expected you was cleverer than to hit me . You see , when it comes to — to muscle , I guess I ’ ve got the bulge on you .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ m not frightened of you .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Now come and wash up these things .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I won ’ t .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Come on .

div.stage: He takes her wrists and tries to drag her to the table . She struggles with him , but cannot release herself . She kicks him as he drags her to the table .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Let me go .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Come on now , my girl . What ’ s the good of making a darned fuss about it ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You brute , how dare you touch me ! You ’ ll never force me to do anything . Let go ! Let go ! Let go !

div.stage: As they reach the table she bends down and bites him . Instinctively he releases her .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Gee , what sharp teeth you ’ ve got .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You cad ! You cad !

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Looking at his hand .I never thought you ’ d bite . That ain ’ t much like a lady .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You filthy cad to hit a woman .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Gee , I didn ’ t hit you . You smacked my face and kicked my shins , and you bit my hand . And then you say I hit you .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With all her passion .You beast ! I hate you .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I don ’ t care about that so long as you wash them cups .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Look .

div.stage: With a sudden sweep of the arm she brushes them off the table , and they fall on the floor and break .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: That ’ s a pity . We ’ re terribly short of crockery . We shall have to drink our tea out of tins now .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I said I wouldn ’ t wash them and I haven ’ t washed them .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: They don ’ t need it now , I guess .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I think I ’ ve won .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: With a smile .Sure . Now take the broom and sweep up all the darned mess you ’ ve made .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I won ’ t .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Look here , my girl , I guess I ’ ve had about enough of your nonsense . You do as you ’ re told and look sharp about it .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You can kill me if you like .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: What ’ s the good of that ? Women are scarce in Manitoba .... Here ’ s the broom .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: If you want that mess swept up you can sweep it up yourself .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You make me tired .He puts the broom into her hands , but she flings it violently away .Look here , if you don ’ t clean up that mess at once , I ’ ll give you the biggest hiding you ’ ve ever had in your life .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Scornfully .You ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Nodding his head .Yours truly . I ’ ve done with larking now .

div.stage: He turns up the sleeves of his sweater . Suddenly she bursts into loud cries .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Help ! Help ! Help !

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: What ’ s the good of that ? There ain ’ t no one within a mile of us . Listen .

div.stage: For a moment they are both silent as they listen to the silence of the prairie .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: If you touch me I ’ ll have you up for cruelty . There are laws to protect me .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I don ’ t care a curse for the laws . I know I ’ m going to be master here . And if I tell you to do a thing you ’ ve darned well got to do it because I can make you . Now stop fooling . Pick up that crockery and get the broom .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I won ’ t .

div.stage: He strides up and is just about to catch hold of her when she shrinks back . She sees he is in earnest . She is terrified by his look .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: No , don ’ t . Don ’ t hurt me .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: He stops and looks at her .I guess there ’ s only one law here , and that ’ s the law of the strongest . I don ’ t know nothing about cities . Perhaps men and women are equal there . But on the prairie a man ’ s master because he ’ s bigger and stronger than a woman .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Frank .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Blast you , don ’ t talk !

div.stage: NORAH pauses , struggling between her pride and her fear . She will not look at her husband . She feels that he is getting impatient . At last , slowly , she bends down and picks up the teapot , the cups and saucers , and puts them on the table . Then she sinks into the chair and bursts into tears . He watches her with a slight smile on his face , but not unkindly .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , I ’ m so unhappy .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Without any anger in his voice .Come on , my girl , don ’ t shirk the rest of it .

div.stage: She looks up and sees the mess of spilt tea on the floor . She gets up slowly , keeping her face away from him , and picks up the broom . She sweeps up . When she has finished she puts the broom in the corner . He watches her all the time . Then she takes up her hat and coat and starts to put them on .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: What are you doing ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ ve done what you made me do . Now I ’ m going .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Where ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What do I care so long as I get away ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You ain ’ t under the impression that there ’ s a first-class hotel round the corner , are you ? because there ain ’ t .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ ll go to the Sharps .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess they ’ re in bed and asleep by now .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I can wake them .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You ’ d never find your way . It ’ s pitch dark .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ ll sleep out of doors , then .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: On the prairie ? Why , you ’ d freeze to death .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What does it matter to you whether I live or die ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: It matters a great deal . Women are scarce in Manitoba .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Are you going to prevent me from going ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Sure .

div.stage: He stands in front of the door and faces her .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You can ’ t keep me here against my will . If I don ’ t go to-night , I can go to-morrow .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: To-morrow ’ s a long way off .

div.stage: She gives a start and looks at him with staring , terrified eyes , her throat is dry with terror .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Frank . What d ’ you mean ?

lg.l: I don ’ t know what silly fancies you had in your head . When I married you
I intended that you should be a proper wife to me .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: But ... but ....She can hardly speak .But you understood .He does not answer . At last she collects herself . She tries to talk calmly and reasonably .I ’ m sorry for the way I behaved , Frank . It was childish of me to struggle with you . You irritated me by the way you spoke .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Oh , I don ’ t mind . I don ’ t know much about women and I guess they ’ re queer . We had to fix things up sometime and I guess there was no harm in getting it over right now .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You ’ ve beaten me all along the line and I ’ m in your power . Have mercy on me .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess you won ’ t have much cause to complain .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I married you in a fit of temper . It was very stupid of me . I ’ m very sorry that I — that I ’ ve been all this trouble to you . Won ’ t you let me go ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: No , I can ’ t do that .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ m no good to you . You ’ ve told me that I ’ m useless . I can ’ t do any of the things that you want a wife to do . You can ’ t be so hard-hearted as to make me pay with all my life for one moment ’ s madness .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: What good would it do if I let you go ? Will you go to Gertie and ask her to take you back again ? You ’ ve got too much pride for that .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I don ’ t think I ’ ve got much pride left .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Don ’ t you think you ’ d better give it a try ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: All the life was so strange to me . In England they think it ’ s so different from what it really is . I thought I should have a horse to ride . I expected dances and tennis parties . And when I came out I was so out of it . I felt in the way . And yesterday they drove me frantic so that I felt I couldn ’ t stay another moment in that house . It was only an impulse . I made a mistake . I didn ’ t know what I was doing . You can ’ t have the heart to take advantage of it .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I knew you was making a mistake , but that was your look out . When I sell a man a horse he can look it over for himself , but I ain ’ t obliged to tell him its faults .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: D ’ you mean to say that after I ’ ve begged you almost on my knees to let me go you ’ ll force me to stay ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Sure .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , I ’ m so unhappy .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Perhaps you won ’ t be when you get used to it .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Desperately .Oh , why did I ever walk into this trap ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Come , my girl , let us let bygones be bygones and give me a kiss .

div.stage: She looks at him for a moment .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ m not in love with you .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guessed that .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: And you ’ re not in love with me .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You ’ re a woman and I ’ m a man .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: D ’ you want me to tell you in so many words that you ’ re physically repellent to me ? The thought of letting you kiss me horrifies and disgusts me .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Good-humouredly .Thank you .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Look at your hands . It gives me goose-flesh when you touch me .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Cutting down trees , diggin ’, looking after horses , don ’ t leave them very white and smooth .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Let me go . Let me go .

div.stage: TAYLOR changes his manner , which has been quite good-humoured , and speaks more sharply and with a certain stern force .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: See here , my girl — you was educated like a lady and spent your life doing nothing — a lady ’ s companion , wasn ’ t you — taking a little dawg out for a walk of a morning and combing out his pretty little coat ? And you look upon yourself as a darned sight better than me . I never had no schooling , and it ’ s a hell of a job for me to write a letter , but since I was so high I ’ ve earned my living . I guess I ’ ve been all over this country . I ’ ve been a trapper and I ’ ve worked on the railroad , and for two years I ’ ve been a freighter . I guess I ’ ve done pretty near everything but serve in a store . Now you just get busy and forget all the nonsense you ’ ve got in your head . You ’ re nothing but an ignorant woman and I ’ m your master . I ’ m going to do what I like with you , and if you don ’ t submit willingly , by God I ’ ll take you as the trappers in the old days used to take the squaws .

div.stage: He steps towards her , and she , escaping from him , seizes his gun , which is lying against the wall . She lifts it and aims at him .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: If you move I ’ ll kill you .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Stopping suddenly .You daren ’ t .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Unless you open the door and let me go I ’ ll shoot you . I ’ ll shoot you .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Advancing one step .Shoot , then .

div.stage: She pulls the trigger . A click is heard , but nothing more .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Gee whiz , you meant it .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Aghast .It wasn ’ t loaded .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Of course it wasn ’ t loaded . D ’ you think I ’ d have stood there and told you to shoot if it had been ? I guess I ain ’ t thinking of committing suicide .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: And I almost admired you .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You hadn ’ t got no reason to . There ’ s nothing to admire about a man who stands five feet off a loaded gun that ’ s being aimed at him . He ’ s a darned fool , that ’ s all .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Throwing the gun aside angrily .You were laughing at me . Now I ’ ll never forgive you .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You ’ d have had me dead as mutton if that gun had been loaded . You ’ re a sport . I never thought you had it in you .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ ll never forgive you .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You ’ re the girl for me , I guess .

div.stage: Before she is prepared he flings his arms round her and tries to kiss her . She struggles desperately , turning her face away from him .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Let me alone . I ’ ll kill myself if you touch me .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess you won ’ t .

div.stage: He gives her a resounding kiss on the cheek and lets her go . Sinking into a chair , she puts her hands up to her flaming cheeks .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , how shameful , how shameful .

div.stage: She sobs in helpless , angry despair . He puts his hand gently on her shoulder .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Hadn ’ t you better cave in , my girl ? You ’ ve tried your strength against mine and it didn ’ t amount to much . You tried to shoot me and I only made you look a darned fool . I guess you ’ re beat , my girl . There ’ s only one law here , and that ’ s the law of the strongest . You ’ ve got to do what I want because I can make you .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Haven ’ t you any generosity ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Not the kind you want , I guess .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , I ’ m so unhappy .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Listen .He puts up his finger and seems to listen intently . She looks at him , but does not speak .Listen to the silence . Can ’ t you hear it , the silence of the prairie ? Why , we might be the only two people in the world , you and me , here in this shack right out in the prairie . Listen . There ain ’ t a sound . It might be the garden of Eden . What ’ s that about male and female created He them ? I guess you ’ re my wife , my girl , and I want you .She gives him a sidelong look of terror , but still does not speak . He takes the lamp and goes to the bedroom door . He opens it and , holding the lamp up high , looks at her . Just to do something she takes the dishcloth and rubs the table with it . She wants to gain time .I guess it ’ s getting late . You ’ ll be able to have a good clean out to-morrow .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: To-morrow .A look of shame , fear , anguish , passes over her face , and then , violently , a convulsive shudder runs through her whole body . She puts her hands to her eyes and walks slowly to the door .END OF THE THIRD ACT

div.head: ACT IV

stage.stage: SCENE : The same as in the previous act , FRANK TAYLOR ’ S shack at Prentice , but there are signs about it of a woman ’ s presence . There is a cloth on the table , and a cushion on the rocking-chair , there are muslin curtains on the window tied back with ribband , and there are geraniums growing in maple-syrup tins . There is a rough bookshelf against the wall , on which is NORAH ’ S small stock of books . Coloured supplements from the Christmas numbers of illustrated papers are pinned neatly on the walls . The packing-cases which had been used as stools have been replaced by rough chairs which TAYLOR has made with his own hands during the winter . When the door of the shack is opened the blue sky is seen and the prairie . NORAH is arranging mustard flowers in a pudding basin on the table . She wears a serge skirt and a neat shirt-waist : she has a healthier look than before , her face is tanned and she has a higher colour . She hears a sound and looks up . TAYLOR enters .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I didn ’ t know you were about .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I ain ’ t got much to do to-day . I ’ ve been out with Sid Sharp and a man come over from Prentice .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Noticing the flowers .Say , what have you got there ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Aren ’ t they pretty ? I picked them just now . They ’ re so cheerful .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Drily .Very .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: A few flowers make the shack look so much more bright and cosy .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Looking round him .You ’ ve made it a real home , Norah . Mrs. Sharp never stops wondering how you done it . Sid was saying only the other day it was because you was a lady . It does make a difference , I guess .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a little smile .I ’ m glad you haven ’ t found me quite a hopeless failure .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess I ’ ve never been so comfortable in all my life . It ’ s what I always said — when English girls do take to the life they make a better job of it than anybody .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What ’ s the man come out from Prentice for ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: After a moment ’ s pause .I guess you ain ’ t been terribly happy here , my girl .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What on earth makes you say that ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You ’ ve got a good memory , I guess , and you ain ’ t ever forgiven me for that first night .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Looking down .I made up my mind very soon that I must accept the consequences of what I ’ d done . I tried to fall in with your ways .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You was clever enough to see that I meant to be master in my own house , and I had the strength to do it .

lg.l: I ’ ve cooked for you and mended your clothes , and
I ’ ve kept the shack clean . I ’ ve been obedient and obliging .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: With a little chuckle .I guess you hated me sometimes .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: No one likes being humiliated as you humiliated me .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Ed ’ s coming out here presently , my girl .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Ed who ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Your brother .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Astounded .Eddie ? When ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Why , right now , I guess . He was in Prentice this morning .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: How d ’ you know ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: He phoned over to Sharp ’ s to say he was riding out .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , how ripping ! Why didn ’ t you tell me before ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I didn ’ t know .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Is that why you asked me if I was happy ? I couldn ’ t make out what was the matter with you .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Well , I guess I thought if you still wanted to quit , Ed ’ s coming would be kind of useful .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Why d ’ you think I want to ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You ain ’ t been very talkative these months , but I guess it wasn ’ t hard to see you ’ d have given pretty near anything in the world to quit .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ m not going back to Eddie ’ s farm , if that ’ s what you mean .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: If he comes before I get back , tell him I won ’ t be long . I guess you won ’ t be sorry to do a bit of yarning with him by yourself .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You ’ re not under the impression I ’ m going to say beastly things about you to him ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: No , I guess not . That ain ’ t your sort . P ’ raps we don ’ t know the best of one another yet , but I reckon we know the worst by now .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Looking at him sharply .Frank , is anything the matter ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Why , no . Why ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You ’ ve seemed different the last few days .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess that ’ s only your fancy . I ’ d better be getting along . Sid and the other fellow are waiting for me .

div.stage: He goes out . NORAH looks at him with a puzzled air , then she gives a touch to the flowers , and gets her work . She sits down at the table and begins to mend a thick woollen sock . Suddenly there is a loud knock at the door . She starts up and runs to open it . EDWARD MARSH is seen standing outside . She gives a cry of delight and flings her arms round his neck . He comes in .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Eddie ! Oh , my dear , I ’ m so glad to see you .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Hulloa there !

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: But how did you come ? I never heard a rig .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Look .

div.stage: She goes to the door and looks out .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Why , it ’ s Reggie Hornby .Calling .Reggie .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Outside .Hulloa !

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: He can put the horse in the lean-to .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Yes .Calling .Reg , give the old lady a feed and put her in the lean-to .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Right-o .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Didn ’ t you see Frank ? He ’ s only just this moment gone out .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: He ’ ll be in presently . Now , come in . Oh , my dear , it is splendid to see you .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: You ’ re looking fine , Norah .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Have you had dinner ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Sure . We got something to eat before we left Prentice .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Well , I ’ ll make you a cup of tea .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: No , I won ’ t have anything , thanks .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You ’ re not a real Canadian yet if you refuse a cup of tea when it ’ s offered you . Well , sit down and make yourself comfortable .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: How are you getting on , Norah ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , never mind about me . Tell me about yourself . How ’ s Gertie ? And what brought you to this part of the world ? And what ’ s Reggie Hornby doing ? And is thingamygig still with you ? You know , the hired man . What was his name ? Trotter , wasn ’ t it ? Oh , my dear , don ’ t sit there like a stuffed pig , but speak to me , or I shall shake you .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: My dear , I can ’ t answer fifteen questions all at once .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , Eddie , I ’ m so glad to see you . You are a duck to come and see me .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Let me get a word in edgeways .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I won ’ t say another syllable . But for goodness ’ sake , hurry up . I want to know all sorts of things .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Well , the first thing is that I ’ m expecting to be a happy father in three or four months .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , Eddie , I ’ m so glad . How happy Gertie must be !

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: She doesn ’ t know what to make of it . But I guess she ’ s pleased right enough . She sends you her love and says she hopes you ’ ll follow her example soon .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ? But you ’ ve not told me what you ’ re doing in this part of the world , anyway .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Smiling .Anyway ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a laugh .I ’ ve practically spoken to no one but Frank for months . I get into his ways of speaking .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Well , when I got Frank ’ s letter about the clearing machine ....

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Interrupting him .Has Frank written to you ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Why , yes . Didn ’ t you know ? He said there was a clearing machine going cheap at Prentice . I ’ ve always thought I could make money down our way if I had one . They say you can clear from three to four acres a day with it . Frank said it was worth my while coming to have a look at it , and he guessed you ’ d be glad to see me .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: How funny of him not to say anything to me about it .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: I expect he wanted to surprise you . Now , how d ’ you like being a married woman ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , all right . Why has Reggie Hornby come with you ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: D ’ you know , I ’ ve not seen you since you were married .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You haven ’ t , have you ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: I ’ ve been a bit anxious about you . That ’ s why , when Frank wrote about the clearing machine , I didn ’ t stop to think about it , but just came .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: It was very nice of you . But why has Reggie Hornby come ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Oh , he ’ s going back to England .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Is he ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Yes , he got them to send him his passage at last . His ship doesn ’ t sail till next week , and he said he might just as well stop off here and say good-bye to you .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: How has he been getting on ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: What do you expect ? He looks upon work as something that only damned fools do . Where ’ s Frank ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , he ’ s out with Sid Sharp . That ’ s our neighbour . He has the farm you passed on your way here .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Getting on all right with him , Norah ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Of course . What ’ s that boy doing all this time ? He is slow , isn ’ t he ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: It ’ s a great change for you , this , after the sort of life you ’ ve been used to .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: To change the topic .I was rather hoping you ’ d have some letters for me . I haven ’ t had any for a long time .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: There now , I ’ ve got a head like a sieve . Two came by the last mail and I didn ’ t send them on because I was coming myself .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You haven ’ t forgotten them ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: No , here they are .

lg.l: They don ’ t look very exciting . One ’ s from
Agnes Pringle . She was a lady ’ s companion that I used to know in
Tunbridge Wells . And the other ’ s from Mr. Wynne .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Who ’ s he ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , he was Miss Wickham ’ s solicitor . He wrote to me once before to say he hoped I was getting on all right .Putting the letters on the table .I don ’ t think I want to hear from people in England any more .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: My dear , why d ’ you say that ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: It ’ s no good thinking of the past , is it ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Aren ’ t you going to read your letters ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Not now . I ’ ll read them when I ’ m alone .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Don ’ t mind me .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: It ’ s so silly of me , but letters from England always make me cry .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Looking at her sharply .Norah , aren ’ t you happy here ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Yes , why shouldn ’ t I be ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Why haven ’ t you written to me once since you were married ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I hadn ’ t got much to say .With a smile .And after all , I ’ d been practically turned out of your house .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Puzzled .I don ’ t know what to make of you .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Nervous and almost exasperated .Oh , don ’ t cross-examine me , there ’ s a dear .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Frank Taylor ’ s kind to you and all that sort of thing , isn ’ t he ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Quite .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: When I asked you to come and stay on the farm I thought it wouldn ’ t be long before you married , but I didn ’ t expect you ’ d marry one of the hired men .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , my dear , don ’ t worry about me .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: It ’ s all very fine to say that . You ’ ve got no one in the world belonging to you but me , and when — when our mother died , she said : “ You ’ ll take care of Norah , won ’ t you , Eddie ?”

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a sob in her voice .Oh , don ’ t , don ’ t .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Norah .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With an effort at self-possession .We ’ ve never quarrelled since the first day I came here . Here ’ s Reggie .

div.stage: She turns to him with relief . HORNBY is dressed in a blue serge suit and again looks like a well-groomed English gentleman .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Gaily .I was wondering what on earth you were doing with yourself .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Shaking hands with her .I say , this is a very swell shack you ’ ve got .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ ve tried to make it look pretty and homelike .

div.stage: MARSH catches sight of the bowl of mustard flowers .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Hulloa , what ’ s this ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Aren ’ t they pretty ? I ’ ve only just picked them . Mustard flowers .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: We call it weed . Have you got much of it ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh yes , lots . Why ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Oh , nothing .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: To HORNBY .I hear you ’ re going home .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Yes , I ’ m fed up with God ’ s own country . Nature never intended me to be an agricultural labourer .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What are you going to do now ?

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: With immense conviction .Loaf !

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Amused .Won ’ t you get bored ?

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: I ’ m never bored . It amuses me to look at other people do things . I should hate my fellow creatures to be idle .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a faint smile .I should have thought one could do more with life than lounge about clubs and play cards with people who don ’ t play as well as oneself .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: I quite agree with you . I ’ ve been thinking things over very seriously this winter . And I ’ m going to look out for a middle-aged widow with money who ’ ll adopt me .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I remember that you have decided views about the White Man ’ s Burden .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: All I want is to get through life comfortably . I don ’ t mean to do a stroke more work than I ’ m obliged to , and I ’ m going to have the very best time I can get .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Smiling .I ’ m sure you will .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: The moment I get back to London I ’ m going to stand myself a slap-up dinner at the Ritz , then I shall go and see a musical comedy at the Gaiety , and after that I ’ ll have a slap-up supper at Romano ’ s . England , with all thy faults , I love thee well .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I suppose it ’ s being alone with the prairie all these months , things which used to seem rather funny and clever — well , I see them quite differently now .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Coolly .I ’ m afraid you don ’ t altogether approve of me .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Not disagreeably .You haven ’ t got pluck .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: I don ’ t know about that . I expect I have as much as anyone else , only I don ’ t make a fuss about it .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , pluck to stand up and let yourself be shot at — I daresay . But pluck to do the same monotonous thing day after day , plain , honest , hard work — you haven ’ t got that . You ’ re a failure , and the worst of it is , you ’ re not ashamed of it . It fills you with self-satisfaction .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Rule Britannia , and what price the Union Jack ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a laugh .You ’ re incorrigible .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: I am .... I suppose there ’ s nothing you want me to take home . I shall be going down to Tunbridge Wells to see mother . Got any messages ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I don ’ t know that I have . Eddie has just brought me a couple of letters . I ’ ll have a look at them .She opens Miss Pringle ’ s letter , reads two or three lines , and gives a cry .Oh !

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: What ’ s the matter ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What does she mean ?Reading .“ I ’ ve just heard from Mr. Wynne about your good luck , and I have another piece of good news for you .”She puts the letter down and quickly opens the solicitor ’ s . She takes out of the envelope a letter and a cheque . She glances at it .A cheque — for five hundred pounds .... Oh , Eddie , listen .Reading .“ Dear Miss Marsh ,— I have had several interviews with Mr. Wickham in relation to the late Miss Wickham ’ s estate , and I ventured to represent to him that you had been very badly treated . Now that everything is settled he wishes to send you the enclosed cheque as some recognition of your devoted service to his late aunt ....” Five hundred pounds !

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: That ’ s a very respectable sum .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: I could do with that myself .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ ve never had so much money in all my life .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: But what ’ s the other piece of good news that Miss Stick-in-the-mud talks about ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , I forgot .She takes Miss Pringle ’ s letter up again and begins to read it .“... Piece of good news for you . I write at once so that you may make your plans accordingly . I told you in my last letter of my sister-in-law ’ s sudden death , and now my brother is very anxious that I should live with him . So I am leaving Mrs. Hubbard , and she wishes me to say that if you care to have my place as her companion she will be very pleased to have you . I have been with her for thirteen years , and she has always treated me like an equal . She is very considerate , and there is practically nothing to do but to exercise the dogs . The salary is thirty-five pounds a year .”

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Both letters are addressed to Miss Marsh . Don ’ t they know you ’ re married ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: No . I never told them .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: What a lark ! You could go back to Tunbridge Wells , and none of the old frumps would ever know you ’ d been married .

div.stage: NORAH gives a sudden start when he says this and stares at him with wide-open eyes . There is a moment ’ s pause .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Just clear out for a minute , Reg . I want to speak to Norah .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Right-o .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Norah , d ’ you want to clear out ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What on earth makes you think that ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: You gave him such a look when he mentioned it .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ m bewildered . Did Frank know anything about this ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: My dear , how could he ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: It ’ s so extraordinary . He was talking about my going away just now .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Quickly .Why ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh !

div.stage: She realises that she has betrayed the secret inadvertently .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Norah , for goodness ’ sake tell me if there ’ s anything the matter . After all , it ’ s now or never . You ’ re keeping back something from me . Aren ’ t you getting on well together ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: In a low voice .Not very .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Why didn ’ t you let me know ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I was ashamed .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: But you say he ’ s kind to you .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ ve got nothing to reproach him with .

lg.l: I felt that something was wrong . I knew you couldn ’ t be happy with him .
A girl like you and a hired man . The whole thing was horrible . Thank God
I ’ m here and you ’ ve got this chance .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What d ’ you mean ?

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: You ’ re not fit for this life . You ’ ve got a chance to go back to England . For God ’ s sake take it . In six months all you ’ ve gone through here will seem nothing but a hideous dream .He is suddenly struck by the expression of her face .Norah , what ’ s the matter ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Tragically .I don ’ t know .

div.stage: HORNBY comes in again .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: I say , here ’ s someone coming to see you .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Me ?She goes to the door and looks out .Oh , it ’ s Mrs. Sharp . Whatever brings her here on foot ? She never walks a step if she can help it . She ’ s the wife of my neighbour .... Good-afternoon , Mrs. Sharp .

div.stage: MRS. SHARP enters . She is a middle-aged woman , red in the face , stout and rather short of breath . She wears an old sun-bonnet , a faded shirt-waist , none too clean , and a rather battered skirt .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Come right in .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: Good-afternoon to you , Mrs. Taylor . I ’ m all in a perspiration . I ’ ve not walked so far in months .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: This is my brother .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: Your brother ? Is that who it is ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Smiling .It seems to surprise you .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: I was so anxious , I couldn ’ t stay indoors . I went out to see if I could catch sight of Sid , and I walked on and then I saw the rig what ’ s outside , and it give me such a turn , I thought it was the inspector . I just had to come . I was that nervous .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Is anything the matter ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: You ’ re not going to tell me you don ’ t know about it ? Why , Sid and Frank haven ’ t been talking about anything else since Frank found it .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Found what ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: The weed .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: With a slight gesture towards the pudding bowl of flowers .You have got it , then ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: It ’ s worse at Taylor ’ s . But we ’ ve got it too .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What does it mean ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: We can ’ t make out who reported us . It isn ’ t as if we had any enemies .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Oh , there ’ s always someone to report you . No one ’ s going to take the risk of letting it get on his own land .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: Looking at the mustard blossom .And she has them in the house as if they were flowers .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Tell me what she means , Eddie .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: My dear , these pretty little flowers which you ’ ve picked to make your shack look bright and homelike — they may mean ruin .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Eddie !

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: You must have heard us talk about the weed . We farmers have three enemies to fight — frost , hail , and weed .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: We was hailed out last year . Lost our crop . We never got a dollar for it . And if we lose it this year too — why , we may just as well quit .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: When it gets into your crop you ’ ve got to report it , and if you don ’ t one of the neighbours will . And then they send an inspector along , and if he condemns it , why you just have to destroy the crop , and all your year ’ s work is lost . You ’ re lucky if you ’ ve got a bit of money in the bank and can go on till the next crop comes along .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: We ’ ve only got a quarter section and five children . It ’ s not much money you can save then .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Are they out with the inspector now ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: Yes . He came out from Prentice this morning .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: This is a bad job for Frank .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: Oh , he hasn ’ t got the mouths to feed that we have . He can hire out again . But what ’ s to become of us ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I wonder why he never told me .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: I guess he ’ s in the habit of keeping his troubles to himself and you ’ ve not taught him different yet .

div.stage: NORAH gives her a quick look , but seeing the woman is all on edge with nervousness does not answer .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: You must hope for the best , Mrs. Sharp .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: Sid says we ’ ve only got it in one place , but perhaps he ’ s only saying it so I shouldn ’ t worry . You know what them inspectors are . They don ’ t lose nothing by it . It don ’ t matter to them if you starve all the winter .

div.stage: She gives a sob and heavy tears roll down her cheeks .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh don ’ t — don ’ t cry , Mrs. Sharp . After all , it may be all right .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: They won ’ t condemn the crop unless it ’ s very bad . Too many people have got their eyes on it . The machine agent , the loan company .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: What with the hail that comes and hails you out and the frost that kills your crop just when you ’ re beginning to count on it , and the weed — I can ’ t bear it any more . If we lose this crop I won ’ t go on . I ’ ll make Sid sell out and we ’ ll go home . We ’ ll take a little shop somewhere . That ’ s what I wanted to do from the beginning , but Sid — he had his heart set on farming .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You couldn ’ t go back now . You ’ d never be happy in a little shop . And if you ’ d stayed in England you ’ d have been always at the beck and call of somebody else . And you own the land . You couldn ’ t do that in England . When you come out of your door and look at the growing wheat , aren ’ t you proud to think it ’ s yours ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: You don ’ t know what I ’ ve had to put up with . When the children came , only once I had a doctor . The other times Sid was the only help I had . I might have been an animal . I wish I ’ d never come to this country .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: How can you say that ! Your children are strong and healthy . Why , they ’ ll be able to help you in the work soon . You ’ ve given them a chance that they ’ d never have got at home .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: Oh , it ’ s all very well for them . They ’ ll have it easy . I know that . But we ’ ve had to pay for it , Sid and me .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You see , you were the first . It ’ s bitter work opening up a new country and perhaps it ’ s others who reap the harvest . But I wonder if those who start don ’ t get a reward that the later comers never dream of .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: She ’ s right there , Mrs. Sharp . I shall never forget what I felt when I saw my first crop spring up and thought that never since the world began had wheat grown on that little bit of ground .... I wouldn ’ t go back to England now for anything in the world . I couldn ’ t breathe .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: You ’ re a man . You have the best of it and all the credit .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: People don ’ t know . You mustn ’ t blame them . It ’ s only those who ’ ve lived out on the prairie who know that the hardships of opening up a new country fall on the women . But the men who are their husbands , they know .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: I guess they do , Mrs. Sharp .

div.stage: NORAH , on her knees beside her , strokes MRS. SHARP ’ S hands . MRS. SHARP gives her a grateful smile .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: Thank you for speaking kindly to me , my dear . I ’ m that nervous , I hardly know what I ’ m saying .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Sid and Frank will be here in a minute , surely .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: And you ’ re right , my dear , I couldn ’ t go back any more . If we lose our crop , well , we must wait till next year . We shan ’ t starve . One ’ s got to take the rough with the smooth , and take it all in all , it ’ s a good country .

div.stage: FRANK TAYLOR comes in .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Frank .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: Starting to her feet .Where ’ s Sid ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Why he ’ s up at your place . Hulloa , Ed . I saw you coming along in the rig . Morning , Reg . I wasn ’ t expecting to see you .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Pleasant surprise for you .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: What ’ s happened ? Tell me what ’ s happened .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Mrs. Sharp came here because she was so anxious .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Cheerfully .Oh , you ’ re all right .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: With a gasp .We are ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Sure . Only a few acres has got to go . That won ’ t hurt you .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: Thank God for that . And it ’ s going to be the best crop we ever had . It ’ s the finest country in the world .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You ’ d better be getting back . Sid ’ s taken the inspector up to give him some dinner .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: He hasn ’ t ? That ’ s just like Sid . It ’ s a mercy there ’ s plenty . I ’ ll be getting along right now .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Don ’ t walk . There ’ s Eddie ’ s rig . Reggie will drive you over .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHARP
sp.p: Oh , thank you kindly . I ’ m not used to walking so much and I ’ m tired out . Good-afternoon , Mrs. Taylor .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Good-bye . Reggie , you don ’ t mind driving Mrs. Sharp back ? It ’ s only just over a mile .

sp.speaker: HORNBY
sp.p: Not a bit .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: I ’ ll come and help you put the mare in .

div.stage: MRS. SHARP and HORNBY go out .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: I guess it ’ s a relief to you now you know , Frank .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Terrible .... I ’ d like to have a talk with you presently , Ed .

sp.speaker: MARSH
sp.p: Right you are .He goes .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ’ m so thankful it ’ s all right . Poor thing , she was in such a state .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: They ’ ve got five children to feed . I guess it makes a powerful lot of difference to them .

lg.l: I wish you ’ d told me before . I felt that something was worrying you and
I didn ’ t know what .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: If I saved the crop there didn ’ t seem any use fussing , and if I didn ’ t you ’ d know quite soon enough .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: How could you bear to let me put the flowers here ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess I didn ’ t mind if it made you happy . You didn ’ t know they was only a weed . You thought them darned pretty .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a little smile .It was very kind of you , Frank .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess it ’ s queer that a darned little flower like that should be able to do so much damage .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Why didn ’ t you tell me you ’ d written to Eddie ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess I forgot .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Frank , Eddie brought me some letters from home to-day . I ’ ve had the offer of a job in England .

div.stage: FRANK is just going to make an exclamation , but immediately controls himself and answers quite quietly .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Gee ! I guess you ’ ll take that .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: It ’ s funny that you should have been talking just now of my going away .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Very .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: A little surprised at his manner .Have you any objection ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess it wouldn ’ t make a powerful lot of difference to you if I had .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: What makes you think that ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess you only stayed here because you had to .

div.stage: She goes over to the little window and looks out at the prairie .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Is life always like that ? The things you ’ ve wanted so dreadfully seem only to bring you pain when they come .He gives her a quick look , but does not answer , and she notices nothing .Month after month I used to sit looking at the prairie and sometimes I wanted to scream at the top of my voice just to break the silence . I thought I should never escape . The shack was like a prison . I was hemmed in by the snow and the cold and the stillness .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Are you going to quit right now with Ed ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: With a smile .You seem in a great hurry to be rid of me .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess we ain ’ t made a great success of married life , my girl .... It ’ s rum when you come to figure it out . I thought I could make you do everything I wanted . It looked as if I held a straight flush . And you beat me .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Why , yes . Didn ’ t you know that ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I don ’ t know what you mean .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess I didn ’ t know how strong a woman could be . You was always givin ’ way , you done everything I told you — and all the time you was keepin ’ something from me that I couldn ’ t get at . Whenever I thought to put my hand on you , I guess I found I ’ d only caught hold of a shadow .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I don ’ t know what more you wanted .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess I wanted love .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You ?

div.stage: She looks at him with consternation . His words give her a queer little twist of the heart-strings .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I know you now less than when you ’ d only been a week up at Ed ’ s . I ’ ve lost the trail and I ’ m just floundering around in the bush .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: In a low voice .I never knew you wanted love .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess I didn ’ t either .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I suppose parting ’ s always rather painful .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: If you go back to the Old Country , I guess — I guess you ’ ll never come back .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Rather shyly .Perhaps you ’ ll come over to England one of these days . If you have a couple of good years you could easily shut the place up and run over for the winter .

lg.l: I guess that would be a dangerous experiment . You ’ ll be a lady in
England , and I guess I ’ d be just the hired man .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You ’ d be my husband .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess I wouldn ’ t risk it .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You ’ ll write to me now and then and tell me how you ’ re getting on , won ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Will you want to know ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Smiling .Why , yes .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I ’ ll write and tell you if I ’ m making good . If I ain ’ t , I guess I shan ’ t feel much like writing .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: But you ’ ll make good , Frank . I know you well enough for that .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: Do you ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: I have learnt to respect you during these months we ’ ve lived together . All sorts of qualities which I used to value seem very unimportant to me now . You ’ ve taught me a great deal .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: You ’ ll think of me sometimes , my girl , won ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Smiling .I don ’ t suppose I shall be able to prevent it .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I was an ignorant , uneducated man . I didn ’ t know how to treat you properly . I wanted to make you happy and I didn ’ t seem to know just how to do it .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: You ’ ve never been unkind to me , Frank . You ’ ve been very patient with me .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I guess you ’ ll be happier away from me . I ’ ll be able to think that you ’ re warm and comfortable at home and you ’ ve got plenty to eat .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: D ’ you think that ’ s all I want ?

div.stage: He gives her a rapid glance , and then setting his teeth looks away .

sp.speaker: TAYLOR
sp.p: I couldn ’ t expect you to stay on here , not when you got a chance of going back to the Old Country . This life is all new to you . And you know that one .

sp.speaker: NORAH
sp.p: Oh , yes , I know it — I should think I did .As she pictures to herself the daily round which awaits her , she is filled with a sort of mirthless scorn , and this presently , as she speaks , is mixed with hatred and dismay .At eight o ’ clock every morning a maid will bring me tea and hot water .
